I'm not an expert on the authenticity of Thai cuisine. My partner and I ordered a Pad Se Ew and a Thai Fried Rice with Dungeness Crab as well as a Fried Tofu and a Fried Calamari. The Pad Se Ew was pretty good. It wasn't overly sweet. The Fried Rice was also fairly standard. The good part about the Fried Rice came from the generous helping of crab meat that came with it--a pretty good deal given that most Thai restaurants tend to skimp on the crab. The Fried Tofu and Fried Calamari were lightly fried and crispy, not overly greasy. Portion sizes for our entrees and our tofu were generous although the Fried Calamari was on the smaller-side.

Overall, Thai House Express was good, but it didn't stand out any more than the average Thai restaurant.
author: Jeffrey P.

description: NEW fan. Fast takeout. Like. seriously. You basically place the order and head on over immediately and it will be ready. WINNN.
author: Sancho P.

description: The food was 5 stars for sure, but the attitude from the waiter was condescending and uncalled for. That's still not enough to keep us away from this restaurant though! We will just hope for a different waiter next time.
author: Meredith E.

description: The Thai House Express @ the Castro is a block south (19th Street) of the main shopping and club area, but well worth the extra steps. Last Saturday two of us shared a sumptuous meal of #10 Corn Cake (appetizers), #30 Tom Kah (coconut chicken soup), and #87 Panang (red curry beef) for $35 (plus tax and tip). The soup was especially good with a careful balance of hot spice and mild coconut milk. The beef was not as tender as I would have liked. The corn cakes are a delight every time. The waiter asked how spicy we'd like the dishes and the cook did a perfect job of adjusting the heat. I mention this because it shows how much they care about the diverse customer base in the area.
author: Ted C.

description:
Ehhh.  

In the world of cheap Thai food, this one ain't on the top of my list.  Don't expect a sit-down dinner at this place.  Well, yeah, you can sit down, but it's totally bare-bones dining.  No big thing.  

I do love Thai food, and this is a quick and inexpensive option in my neighborhood.  I've been a couple times and I know by now that the food isn't fresh.

I'm just giving props for those taro balls in coconut milk!  YEP, I said balls in milk--you make your own conclusions.  Mine is creamy starchy mmm-hmmm good.  Take the rest for what it is:  quick eats on the cheap.
author: Angella S.

description: Came here for lunch so tried the specials. About $11, came with soup, appetizer, rice and protein. I had the chicken with peanut sauce, and partner had beef. It was all pretty good and a good deal. We'll be trying the dinner menu soon as we were impressed by what we ate.
author: Vol T.

description:
Be warned: the "vegetarian" soup is NOT VEGETARIAN!! All their soups, including the "vegetarian" options are made with chicken stock. Some of the wait staff will try to claim it is totally vegetarian, but it never is (I have confirmed this with several people who work there).

Otherwise, the food is great, but I am always disappointed that they lie on the menu about their veggie options!
author: JT O.

description:
They recently changed cooks which is why I give it 3 stars instead of 4. Either that or they switched up their yellow curry recipe...bit too spicy for me now.

I like not love: Yellow Curry over rice.

I tried: Pad Thai and Pad See Yew, I prefer the yellow curry though. 

Waiters play favorites so if your male and you flirt, expect a free glass of wine, I've seen it happen ;)
author: Kristy F.

description:
My friend and I had a nice little meal here.

The Pad Kee Mao with beef and pumpkin curry with chicken hit the spot. Larb appetizer could have come with a bit more greens or lettuce, but was a heaping portion.
author: Ameer N.

description:
Heard of this place from a friend and decided to give it a go.
came on a Saturday evening for dinner and was immediately seated.  I was seated on their upper level (not really a 2nd floor, but it is elevated).  which was nice.  the decor is more on the modern side and the place is clean.  

The servers were very friendly and I had ice water down right away within seconds of asking for it.  

Ordered the salmon in banana leaf, yellow curry, and chicken skewers as an appetizer.

The chicken skewers were delicious!  the sauce they provided really made this dish.

Soon afterwards, the main entrees came.

the salmon was cooked just right as the fish was thoroughly cooked yet still soft and juicy.  This dish came with a "special dipping sauce" which complemented the salmon very well.  it looked like a pesto like sauce but it turned out to be a mild hot sauce with some other herbs... really great stuff and supposedly  the "chef special sauce"  i didn't taste any banana flavor so i assume it's just for the presentation looks.

overall, this place gets great marks on decor and cleanliness.  the service was great and of course the food was tasty and well worth the try.  overall judging from this experience, i'd give this place a 4.5 stars since it didn't wow me, but i would still recommend.

expect your bill + tip to be ~$17/person
author: Mike L.

description:
Went here for a late lunch it's nice inside and clean 
we ordered the lunch special soup , salad and rice and choice of appetizer and entree 
soup was not very hot so we sent it back 
portions are kind of small but ok for a lunch special
we had ice cream for dessert total for 2 $ 38 
it was ok don't think I'd go out of my to go again
author: lyn m.

description: The best place to get Thai food in the Castro. Their pad thai and red curry dishes are my favorites. Their veggie eggrolls and these little fried pouch things stuffed with chicken are good too. Their only downfall is the slow service or lack thereof.
author: Fallon P.

description: Fast, efficient, msg loaded food, reasonably priced, good for group gathering or prior to Castro bar hopping/ club dancing.  Difficult to find parking if you drive but it's only two blocks away from Castro station.
author: Alanda B.

description: Regularly grab to go dinners over the years. The prices keep going up and the serving smaller. Now no dishes over rice at dinner so you're looking at $17 for one basic dish. Super lame thing to do to long term customers. Not going back.
author: Fred R.

description: This is the best Thai place in the Castro.  I love their Pumpkin curry and Catfish dish.  They also make a great pork dish, Pork Leg Stew (ka Moo), this is really, really tasty. When you are in the mood for thai and need a reliable place, Thai House Express is the way to go.
author: Natasha F.

description:
I like this place.

I have been coming here off and on for years. I always get the same thing: yellow chicken curry a la carte and a sauvignon blanc (because the only thing better than yellow curry is white wine with yellow curry).

Staff isn't bending over backwards and sometimes doesn't understand what I am saying but that's ok because my yellow chicken curry always tastes the same delicious way.

Hint the dine in portions are larger than the to go portions so if you have some time sit and eat a little and take the rest home for later.

Totally unrelated to the food: if you get a window table the people watching is amazing.
author: dude m.

description: I'm going up to 5. it's not just the best in the 'hood - it's among the best i have had. Always consistent, fast, friendly and delicious.
author: Erica W.

description:
First visit here and very pleased.  
We were greeted and sat promptly with menus.  The food we ordered was delivered in a timely manner and all of it was delicious.  Started with the coconut chicken soup - had a touch of lime which made it even better.  My friend and I had the chicken pad tai and green curry pork.  
To anyone who hasn't had a good experience, give them a another try.
author: Jose R.

description: It was pretty good. Standard american style thai good with nice presentation. No complaints. Very clean. Nice people. Not too busy.
author: Melville M.

description:
Why are there so many princesses writing reviews now?  
You want to be dazzled every time you go out for a meal?  
I've never had a bad experience here.. never.   2 stars only?  GTFO
author: Pete S.

description:
Oh gosh. My true savior after some drinking around the area! 

Marnee Thai is still my favorite Thai place in SF, and i truly miss it. BUT THEN AGAIN, i'm mostly around the Castro; therefore, Thai House fills in the void. Let's break it down girls and boys: "Drunken noodles" is deliciousness (especially when it's spicy!), curries are curry-licious, and everything else is just awesome.. AT A DECENT PRICE and PORTIONS ARE NICE!  Oh, go here every Friday and weekend nights... this place is hoppin and the men are coming in! heheh

To cure your hangovers, a Thai place like this would definitely cure it.
author: Marc K.

description: First time at this restaurant ...tried the crab pad thai ...not good.  Had one piece of crab that I recognized ...I think the rest was fried up in the noodles ...it was so fishy tasting I could not eat it.  Also had the mixed vegetables with peanut sauce ...that was ok, but nothing spectacular.
author: Rich M.

description:
Don't let the name fool you!  The establishment is both fancier than I was expecting with the word 'Express' tacked on the end, and our service wasn't very 'Express' either.

The food was SCRUMPTIOUS as I wolfed down all my Pad See Ewe after eating most of the selections on their appetizer sampler as well.  Yummy yummy yummy thai food.  Spicy (if you ask for it) and wonderful.

I have to knock off one star for the service.  While polite, it was difficult to get our server's attention, and we had to ask twice for the check.  On a date or something, this wouldn't be a big deal - but we had a show to get to.  Don't worry - we made it on time.

Thai House Express will definitely be in my back pocket next time I'm in the Castro.
author: Ellie F.

description: Thai house express is my go-to, reliable, casual staple thai restaurant. Service is fast and though the food is always brought out pretty quickly, it's usually still hot. I only ever order the pad see ew with chicken, which is very good. Can be crowded sometimes on the weekends.
author: Ronnie S.

description:
I'm not sure why everone speaks badly of the service here. I've been twice, and both times the waiter has been polite and efficient. I must be coming on the right days.

I like the space. It's clean and contemporary, and it's a great location if you're wanting to go out in the Castro, since it's right there at the end of the block, past a bunch of bars and clubs. The food was solid. Everything was well-prepared and the portions were pretty standard sized. I did ask for "spicy" and made a joke about it not being "white boy day", that I can definitely take it... and they didn't call my bluff. It was fairly mild still.

Definitely a place I'd return... but not a place where I'd make a special trip.
author: Sean B.

description: This is our go to Thai Restaurant. Great for takeout but also great for dining. Staff is courteous. Favorite dishes are panang curry and peanut sauce with vegetables. There are multiple Thai restaurants nearby by this one is the best.
author: David T.

description:
I can't recollect the exact number of times I've eaten at Thai House Express on Castro, but having lived less than 5 doors up on Castro street for over a year, I can assure myself that it's enough to write an honest review. And honestly, the service here is 90% 'go f*ck yourself - you're inconveniencing me by eating where I work.'  The other 10% is from a nice lady, whom I assume owns or manages the place but rarely serves, or from a one-off server whom I never see twice. 

In a city where Thai food is easily accessible, they need to understand the value of legendary customer service - even in a fast turning eatery like this. While the food itself is quite enjoyable, I've made a commitment to myself to enjoy dining out, and I've experienced equal quality food with much better service at neighborhood competitors: Nirvana and Thai Chef.

If you are here, and are looking for a recommendation, their curries are amazing as well as their flat rice noodle dishes.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Fresh and delicious Thai food. I ordered pumpkin curry, with fresh spring rolls. The pumpkin curry was well balanced, with large chunks of kabucha squash, which added a nice sweetness. The curry was heavy on fresh veggies, and had an impressive kick to it. Which brings me to my final point...the pleasant surprise of Thai House Express's spice scale.

I think Obama's first action after winning the presidency should've been to standardize the spiciness scale in the U.S. How disappointing is it when you order a a vegetable curry with 3.5 stars, and it tastes more like 0 stars. Thai House Express has no such scale. When you ask for it spicy, it comes spicy.
author: Jordan Z.

description: San Francisco certainly isn't at a loss for great Thai food, but visitors to the Castro should take the time to try out Thai Express. Unassuming for the quality of food that it produces, while not inventive or new,  Thai Express always delivers high quality food and service, something that can't always be said of other thai restaurants in town that cater to tourists.
author: Nathan D.

description: Disappointing.  Had green curry with chicken, the crispy noodles with gravy, and the moneybags with cucumber salad. The cucumber salad was my favorite thing.
author: Daniel A.

description:
If you're in Castro and want Thai...this is the spot :) 

When i came in, the first thing i noticed was that I loved the decor. Especially the flower prints on the wall. Service was great and everyone was super friendly and helpful. We went around 7:30 on a Monday night, and it was surprisingly packed which is always a good sign. Their menu was extensive but definitely not overwhelming, and they have all the basics you want when you crave Thai food. Even better, they have a decent wine menu! 

fav dishes of the night:
- tom yum goong soup
- pad thai
- som tum thai (green papaya salad)
- pumpkin curry
- ga prow (minced chicken w/ basil, chili, and bell peppers)

They get their 5th star because of their mango sticky rice dessert. I got some serious mango knowledge that night! Unlike other places who use semi-ripe or stringy fibrous mangoes during the winter season, these were SWEET and left no grossness in your mouth after biting into it. AMAZING FOR THE FREAKING MIDDLE OF WINTER! 

I was told that mangoes that taste stringy are mostly from Mexico, but the sweeter ones come from Guatemala or the Philippines. It obviously shows they know their stuff even down to the last details ...like where to purchase good mangoes :)
author: Kristen C.

description:
This is one of my biased reviews, only because my lovely Thai friends like Lek and Poo work here and they always make sure to take care of me and my guests. (I'm sure they're that way with everyone, but still.)

The food is SOOO good and hot and fast. Usual orders: Neur Kem, Naked Ladies, Moo Tad ala carte, Crab Fried Rice, Spicy Beef Salad, Pad Kee Mao, steamed rice, Roti, Mango Sticky Rice (when in season), and of course, COCONUT JUICE!!!! 

Yes, I can easily just go to the Thai House that's a few blocks from my apartment, but there's something about eating Thai food and then looking at gay porn down the street that caps off my weekend.
author: Maureen B.

description:
Thai House Express has VASTLY improved in the past half year to year since it got slapped on the wrist for a health code violation (you read it right!). 

I live across the street, so had many opportunities to study the health inspector document that was taped to the their front door for many weeks. The slap on the wrist came because Thai House apparently set a pot of curry on the floor -- in all likelihood the commonest of occurrences in Asian, and non-Asian, restaurants -- and were caught red-handed. 

Anyway, I've never, ever gotten sick from eating at this restaurant, but for the past 4 years, it's been quite mediocre in terms of food yumminess, ingredients and service.

2011 is definitely this restaurant's year to start over.

So far they've done a nice, 4+ star job:

Food: 

+ Standard Thai restaurant items with better-than-average-quality ingredients. Veg curry doesn't just mean napa cabbage, but chock full of long beans, big chunks of pumpkin, broccoli, carrots, finely diced lemongrass, and whole leaves of Thai basil.

+ Pad Thai is not flavored with ketchup (as some really lame "Thai cooking at home!" cookbooks advise), but actually fairly complex -- fishy, seared, sweet, and tangy -- for what started out in this world as a humble street food.

Ambience:

+ Patrons of this restaurant are always some of the LEAST annoying :) people in San Francisco, even when they're drunk, which they're usually not. Go Castro.

+ Nice corner spot on the quietest end of the village, so a good place to chill out before or after the busier hangouts of this neighborhood.

Service:

+ Staff have become sweeter since their wrist-slap. 

+ Always nice, and never condescending, about special requests like bringing my own containers for takeout, ingredient substitutions, etc.

Give this place a first, or second, try -- it's one of the Castro businesses that's NOT resting on its laurels, and appears to be trying hard to change, and improve.
author: Susan S.

description: Kind of an average Thai place with decent prices.  I loved the mint lemonade and the Tom Yum soup (be careful, its spicy).   The Pad See Ew was very bland and very nutty tasting but a huge portion.  We didnt' experience any problems with service but the guys next to us were complaining about the menu changing and things not being the same as before.
author: Monica G.

description:
One of the better Thai restaurants i have been to in SF, and it helps that it's close to my house. The service is not the most personable, but their food makes up for it. They also have a pretty quick turnaround, so you can eat and get out in a hurry if you need to. 

Now I am a bit of a nut for a good Pad Thai, and most places don't do it right. This place DOES. So that's a few extra points in my book. Also the other noodle dishes are very good too, especially the Drunken Noodles and the flat wide ones.

I have been here on my own and also with a large group of friends, and each time the food has been tasty and impressive. Not quite spectacular, but also not far off. Hence the 4 stars. 

if you are in the area, or even if you aren't, this place is worth a shout if you want a tasty, dependable, affordable Thai meal.
author: William C.

description: Their whole steamed fish is delicious.  Order it medium spicy and you'll definitely get a kick.  This is my go-to dish.  The 5-spice duck noodle soup was really tasty as well.  I've been coming here for a few years and I love this place.  It's easy to get in, the service is good, and the food is delicious.
author: Tina T.

description:
Fish ball tofu noodle soup = bland.  I added hot pepper and what not, and it still did not help.  I was dearly disappointed.

Tried their fresh shrimp rolls as well....which was okay.  It had more cucumbers than noodles.  Maybe that is just me.

Prices = decent, especially for this area.

Decor = Nice, simple, and I simply love their table by the front door with the bar stool seats.  

Service = Okay.  They were efficient but lacked personality.  Although, some beautiful boys do work there. :-P

Overall, I'll go back for another try.
author: Fannie S.

description: What I thought of this place was just another Thai restaurant. I like the contemporary decor and dishware, but it's not fully elegant and coupled with the menu, it all tells me that this is another medium-priced, medium-tasting, medium-impressiveness establishment. I could've easily walked into another restaurant as easily as I walked into this one. The service was nice and friendly. The pad thai was good. The noodles were not too soft or hard. The currys are pretty mild. The fried banana and mango with sticky rice desserts are the stand out items. The drinks aren't bad. The lunch specials are great, so come here for that.
author: Jennifer W.

description: A friend of mine took me here and I tried a few items from the duck with garlic noodles to bbq chicken. The bbq chicken was alright when comparing it to others but the curry dishes and the duck were a standout. A very great atmosphere and I love the loud music and very trendy decor as well. Parking is bad of course but park far so you can walk around Castro and walk off the food after your meal.
author: Danster L.

description: Love it. I don't fully understand what they do to the pad Thai to make it so good and unique but this place is awesome. Typically good service, quick and good portion size. Everything I want!
author: Greg S.

description: I swear to god i have never and probably never will have a better pad thai omfg. 5 stars literally only for this dish. Other than that, the pineapple fried rice was not good and lacked flavors, papaya salad and fried banana and ice cream was just okay
author: Jenny N.

description: I've always found the staff here to be friendly and attentive. The food is excellent (especially the Larb with duck if you like lime, garlic/onions, & cilantro). Never felt rushed. To the person who did feel rushed, maybe you were lingering while there was a crowd of hungry people? Pay your bill and go get coffee and dessert at one of SF's fine cafés if you want to linger!
author: Josh S.

description:
Perhaps there is a decent restaurat in the Castro after all!

Excellent vegetarian soup!

I am curious to try more food here. I will most certainly be back.
author: Miriam W.

description: I went here with one of my best friends recently. This was actually my second time to this restaurant. I thought everything was absolutely delicious and the service was great too! Would definitely come back!
author: Itai B.

description: I recently had a job interview and decided to treat myself to some Thai food afterwards, I found this place in the Castro and was very happy to find that they had an amazing lunch special for $11. What do you get for $11, well I chose to have the veggie egg rolls, chicken Pra Ram with peanut sauce, soup, and salad. The server was very friendly and it was not busy at all when I arrived. I was seated promptly and enjoyed my meal. The portions were just perfect and I was left feeling full and satisfied, such a better feeling that overfed and stuffed. I recommend this place for sure!
author: Alex T.

description: One of my very favorite Thai Restaurants to eat at! The selection is good. The prices are reasonable and so are the portions. If you ask for hot... they won't hold back! LoL! If you are looking for an excellent Thai place in SF... then this would be it! Enjoy!
author: Matt C.

description: I just popped into this place for takeout. The wait was under 10 minutes from ordering, and the dish I ordered was good and still hot when I made it home about 25 minutes later. The red curry with shrimp and pineapple was flavorful, mild, and the shrimp were cooked well.
author: Chibi K.

description: My neighborhood Thai joint. I'm into the ga prow and the yellow curry with chicken. Attentive service every time I've eaten here. Reliably tasty. I'm happy it's so close by.
author: Kent L.

description: I've been here dozens of times. It's hard to complain about Thai food anyway, but this one is clearly the best Thai food in town, we're not talking high end, we're talking just good Thai food.
author: Hendrik G.

description:
Hey, Thai House Express On Castro, I don't need you to be a b*tch when I call in to place my phone order.

Who cares about the food when every experience involves one to three stuck-up employees?
author: J S.

description:
This Thai House has okl thai food.  We recently went there, after many times before, and noticed the food is very salty.  Oh, don't order food to go because if you do, your to go food will be awful!  

There is better Thai food in the Castro. Thai Chef has better food.
author: Truong P.

description: Very slow service, not happy! The food is good if not just ok but the slow and tiresome service is what drags this place down. They all appeear to busy but doing what is the question. I have had beeter luck with take out rather than seating.
author: Tyler S.

description:
I haven't been here in a few years.  I've been hearing how they've gone downhill, but I had to find out for myself.  

My four test dishes are things every Thai restaurant should do well.  It's not fair to rate a place on one dish, or on the mood of the server.

Unfortunately, The Thai House Express on Castro managed to prepare all four dishes poorly, and nobody came back to say "how's everything?"  

Som Tam - Green Papaya Salad (Limp, vaguely lime-flavored, no chilies at all, no dried shrimps, and generally lackluster)

Garlic Eggplant with Beef (heavy dark plum sauce gravy and very salty)

Green Chicken Curry (too much coconut milk and not curry flavor to make it hot and memorable)

Pad Thai (unremarkable, soggy, bland flavor)

Ouch!  It really was painful to pay for an expensive meal that tasted so bad.  Thai food should always be interesting, and never bland!

Maybe I should have asked for the dishes prepared Thai style?  But I thought that would go without saying in a Thai place.
author: tout le monde a.

description:
I really enjoyed this place. I went to this location to meet up with a couple of friends that I had not seen in a while. 
The prices were reasonable, the presentation was appealing, and the food was delicious. I would definitely come back here.
author: Joe V.

description:
We're settling in to our new hood here in Castro and per some yelpers reccos we tried to find out new Thai place. Sure enough, yelp never fails. 

Great food (the little minced chicken packets are so yummy, I enjoyed my eggplant, and the kow soi chicken was great as well). The service was fast and very friendly (thanks nice waiter from boston!) and my food was ready in ten minutes.
author: Nikki M.

description: This place has really nice upbeat energy. The staff is very attentive and friendly. The wait isn't too long, and the food usually doesn't take too long to come out. I enjoy the atmosphere and the different selections available at this restaurant.
author: Tom T.

description:
went back here recently on a trip to SF. I used to live around the corner from here and eat there sometimes twice a week. It's the BEST in Thai food that I've had. the flavors are just really amazing and tasty. 

we ordered all our old favorites (beef curry), pineapple rice and a couple new items. our party shared everything, family style. we just smiled and chowed down, sometimes managing to get a few words in. put really enjoying the food. never had anything I didn't like from here and the staff is always really nice and quick. favorite Thai place ever.
author: michella s.

description:
I liked it. I would say it is very comparable to most of the good Thai restaurants in the City. Authentic, not afraid to add spices when requested for spicy, fast, and the service was fantastic. Jack, our server, made sure that we had enough food, water was refilled periodically, and served with a smile. 

It probably helped that I dined with a few of his friends as well. As for the food..............it's good. If I lived in this neighborhood this would be my go to place for Thai. I probably wouldn't come here from where I live, but people who live around here should. 

We had the Curry chicken, Fried fish with peanut sauce, spicy ground pork with basil and peppers. Every single dish was cooked perfectly. The food is flavorful, prepared well, and encaptures the true essence of Thai cuisine in my opinion. 

3 dishes with 3 orders of rice came out to around 32 dollars. If you like Osha on Geary, Chabaa, Marnee then you are going to like this place.
author: jason g.

description: Absolutely one of our favorite thai restaurants we've been to in SF. Great service! Plenty of seating.. Great for groups! The food is super delicious and the wine selection is great! Loved the merlot... can't wait to go back... Definitely become one of our favorites in SF...
author: Josh G.

description:
I have been to Thai House Express twice. The first time was last December, when we visited for Christmas. The last time was this past May. Both times I was drawn for one dish: the crab pad Thai.

What is great about this place is that it is clean, it is busy but never completely packed, and the servers are very fast, very accurate, and just very good. You don't wait for anything here.

The ambiance and decor fits, too. It has sort of clean, whitewashed feel to it, which works for its express character. You're having table service, but it is speedy and minimal, which is the intent. Nothing is overdone.

The food portions are generous. What I like about the crab pad Thai is its inventiveness. It is tender, savory, and the flavors work so well. It is one of must-haves for me when we visit the Castro.

The only drawback, and it is a very minor one, is the beer selection. There are only two that I recall. Perhaps that is in keeping the minimalist and speedy approach. Perhaps they could add one or two and still be fine. Either way, it's the only thing close to a drawback.

This is definitely one of the delights in the Castro. In an area were service has gone down hill, think of Harvey's just down the hill and how bad their servers have gotten, this place is an example of what fast, inexpensive dining should be. It's good, very good, and it does everything well.

Just add a few more beers. That's all I want.

Absolutely recommended.
author: Mike H.

description:
I used to live closer to the area, and I remember having plenty of good meals here. There aren't a lot of good & decently-priced places to eat on the Castro strip, so this is a nice addition to the area. 

The most memorable menu item is the por-pier pak (egg rolls stuffed with noodles/veggies), which comes with an AMAZING sweet and sour sauce. It's tempting not to order 2 of these!

The pad thai is really great. It's sweet more than it is spicy, which is nice when you're sharing a bunch of entrees/appetizers. 

I got a coconut milk-based soup here once that was a little too coconut-y for me. I also tried the tofu tod once, which was also kind of whatever. But I think fried tofu by itself is boring by default, so...

This place is definitely worth a try if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Rachel F.

description: Addicted to this place. I get my chicken cashew fix at least once a week and this restaurant is always prompt, consistent, and affordable.
author: Mike B.

description:
Last night is my last time to this restaurant!  Never again!

The waiters, they are rude.  We were having dinner and all they did was trying to clean up our table--moving in the menus, giving us the bill, running our credit card and starring at our table--in a very subtle way to tell us to hurry up so that they can sit the next person.  I find it very impolite!
NO MORE THAI HOUSE FOR ME!!!
author: D. Dien N.

description:
Having seen a movie at the Castro on a Friday night, I made the decision that I needed some tasty food in my belly to accompany the moving images still churning around in my head.  Someone suggested Thai food as it is both tasty and veggie-friendly, and so we made the minuscule mosey over to Thai House Express.

Thai House Express is a trendy looking place.  The decor is rather bare-bones, though the hip-looking people in their skinny-looking jeans and chunky-looking glasses tend to provide most of the visual stimulation.  And we had a lot of time to look around, as the wait for a table was surprisingly long.  We were given menus and were able to order ahead of time, which was nice.  But another group of the same size was seated first, even though they arrived after us, which was a little less nice.

The menu was extensive, and very vegetarian-friendly.  Pretty much anything can be made with tofu, and my friends ended up with piles of various vegetables on top of brown rice.  They looked (and, I'm told, were) super good.  We also got spring rolls and, perhaps to compensate for being so darn healthy, the corn cakes.  Not being one to pass up curry, I got the gang koor goong: shrimp in red curry, pineapples, tomatoes, and basil.  The spring rolls were deliciously average, the corn cake was deliciously fried (and a refreshing change of pace!), and the curry held its own quite well.  It was creamy with a little heat as I was anticipating, but I was a little disappointed by the amount of delightful chunky bits in my curry - it looked a bit more like soup, though it did taste excellent over the rice.

The service was really quite alright once we were seated, and I'm mostly content with the prices - Thai House Express could charge for ambiance if it wanted to, but they don't and I appreciate that very much.  If I'm in the Castro, I'll likely show up again and try some of the other dishes.  It's legit and it's tasty, but it's no reason to make a pilgrimage across the city.  Unless, of course, you just like taking pilgrimages.
author: Becca S.

description: We have never had anything but great food and a wonderful experience. We have been going to Thai House Express for over 10 years and love coming back. The food is westernized and still so good, but if you want it more authentic (spicier and in some dishes, less sweet) don't hesitate to ask.
author: Art D.

description: Really good Thai food and friendly service. What was most impressive was the service I received after I realized I was overcharged. I had dinner with 3 friends and we split the bill with 2 credit cards and cash (not a common practice as I know this is a pain for wait staff). I called 2 days later and Ed promptly looked into it and called me back the same day confirming that he would take care of it and said if there was any other problems to call him back. I checked my credit card statement and it was taken care of just like he promised. Well done!
author: Carolyn H.

description:
Delicious pineapple and shrimp curry. I asked for spicy and boy did I get it! 

Definately worth a little fire though!
author: Marcus B.

description:
Pretty authentic and tasty Thai in the Castro. The menu has a lot of typical favorites as well as specials and the staff is super friendly. Best of all its cheap, clean, and fast. 

update: I am sad to say I docked a star...the two times I've gone I noticed I get incredibly thirsty afterwards... there must be some major msg to aftect me that much. It still tastes damn good if you're ok with msg
author: Lainy C.

description:
Pretty decent Thai food at a good price.  Most entrees are under $10 and for that amount you could probably finish the dish if you are a big man and /or very hungry but I've never been able to manage it.

I really like the curries here, especially he curried noodles.

Pretty full in the evenings but no problem during the day.

Bike Parking: designated bike racks along Castro St.
author: Jean K.

description:
Whenever I'm craving some Tom Kha Gai I know exactly who to turn to...[Enter] Thai House Express. There's just something about the warm broth of coconut and chicken soup resulting in a milky, aromatic, sour, salty, and super appetizing taste. A must try on a cool San Francisco night!

I'm also a fan of their #72 (Chicken Cashew Main) served either A La Carte (with a side of rice) or as a main. One thing is for sure, I never leave here hungry. There is plenty of food to go 'round. 

A great place to start off the night clubbing with some good friends and good Thai food!
author: Andrew S.

description:
We've eaten here on three occasions and have been blown away every time. Most recently we ate here with a group of friends and order 12 dishes, all which were amazing. 

The customer service is hit or miss. Of the three visits, the customer service on was point most recently. 

Amazing dishes to order: pineapple fried rice, salmon in curry sauce, vegetarian pumpkin curry. These are my top three. 

The food is so amazing, they might figure they don't need to stress customer service. The only thing holding me back from giving a 5 star is the customer service.

and the prices are reasonable.
author: Sandra And Mailee H.

description:
I have to say I have gone to this place many many time over the years its been there and I honestly have had no problems and the food was up to par. This time and its been 4-5 months since I have been but so many new face working there and yes it was at 630 pm friday night BUT there was only 2 other table there and 7 service people working , the sad part is they seated up or I should say we walked to the table we wanted and then the server brought water and well 10 minutes later we r sitting and sitting watching these servers walk by us going in and out of the kitchen eating  and chatting with each other and  seeing that we were just watching them and still NOT ONE came to table to take order, I got up when they all were huddled around the front computer area and I said can one of u take our order we have BEEN ready!  One came over and took all our orders and after that they brought the food which honestly was OK not really anything special even tho the menu had change which most would think that would mean more flavor or better quality.but all in all I was pretty disappointed in my used to be fav Thia house here in the hood. I will think twice about going when there r so many options in the hood. 
NOTE to SERVERS  please pay attention to your patrons esp when u work on tips due to myself I will not leave one when i can get better service at Burger King.
Randy Scorpio
author: Randy M.

description:
The Food is great and the staff is always friendly and pleasant, what more could you ask for in a place to eat.

Big groups are easily handled here.

Oh yeah, the price is reasonable for the Castro and San Francisco.
author: T.J. L.

description:
I was chillin out here just last week!  It was fairly crowded, but my party got our table in no time.  I ordered the Pad Kee Mao, my traditional favorite for Thai dishes.  I know, I'm lame...I get the same damn thing every time I want to satisfy my Thai cravings.  This also means my palette is well adjusted to hone in on specific aromas and taste for Pad Kee Mao...whatever the hell that means.  

Anyway, the Pad Kee Mao was very delicious!  Being left-handed, I ate with a spoon on my right hand and a fork on my left, as suggested to me by this Thai lady at another restaurant (seems to be the standard way of eating for the Thai folks, apparently).  Supposedly, you bring the spoon to the mount (or mouth, whatever) and never the fork...the spoon should have more droplets of Thai sauces/spices per area than a fork can ever have.  Ending result:  Not sure if it was the method, but damn the food was delicious!  Very flavorful.  The basil was done right (not black and overcooked like some places).  However,  I didn't like how it was hardly spicy at all (and I asked the kind waitress to make it as spicy as possible!).  I've tasted spicier things in...fish and grits than I do in this Pad Kee Mao dish...

I snatched a few noodles from a Pad Thai dish my friend ordered when she wasn't looking, and I gotta say...that Pad Thai dish is as good as they say it is! ... or maybe it just taste better when you have to work for it. =P  

Regardless, I recommend this place for a decent meal.  The price is very fair for the quality of the food they have.
author: Dararith L.

description:
Came here after watching Alton Brown at the Castro Theater (which was an amazing show!). This is some of the better Thai food I've had.

- Fish Cakes (Tod Mun) - These were ok. I've had better. They lacked in flavor a little, but the consistency was just right - a little spongy (in a good way!).
- Basil Chicken (Ga-Prow) - How do they make ground chicken taste so good!? I normally find ground chicken to be pretty gross (well, more like tasteless), but the flavor of this dish blew my mind. Strong basil influence, a little spicy, and an umami sauce. Definitely try this dish, which also comes with beef or pork.
- Beef Green Curry - Very good green curry. At the end, we had some sauce and some rice left, so I dumped the rice in the sauce and finished it all!
- Seafood with Spicy Basil - This dish was good, but not too memorable. If you like seafood, I would recommend it.
- Taro Balls in Creamy Coconut (Bua Loi) - Little pillow-y taro pieces of heaven. A consistency somewhere between mochi and gnocchi, but with taro! And you can't go wrong with coconut milk. Delicious!!

I was deciding whether to give this place 4 or 5 stars, but the Basil Chicken and the Taro dessert made me bump it up to 5.
author: Angel C.

description: I have been here couple times for the past years. The food here sometime is good but the quality was not consistent. I like how they have the variety of dishes that you do not find in other Thai restaurants. However, the dishes are fairly salty every time I eat there. The service is not a super. Overall, there is nothing standout of this place. I do not have a desire to come back here while there are so many better Thai restaurant out there and better food and service. I think this place can definitely improve there quality!
author: Luong T.

description: I keep thinking that eggplant at Thai restaurants will be flavorful.  It's sort of analogous to my dating history.  I truly love eggplant, but even with chicken or red peppers or brown rice it never quite tastes better than average.  And you have to thrown down more money than you want.  The Express is also appropriate.  In and gone before you know it.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
Some of the best Thai in 'da hood.  And you know how you are when you want something and you want it to be good?  Consistent?  That is how I view Thai House Express.  This is probably my 10th time there....

Dinner last night was calling, and it wasn't going to be coming from my kitchen.  Went over to Thai House Express and wasn't disappointed.

Chicken Skewers with Peanut Sauce.  Always good.  Chicken is always fresh and never fatty.  I am not a peanut sauce fan, but my dining parter was and said it was great.

Then it was TOm Kha Gai (hot and sour chicken soup).  A nice mix of coconut milk with lemon grass, plenty of chicken with mushrooms and onions.  This is something that is ALWAYS ordered.  ALWAYS, did I say?  Yes.

Pad Thai - now you can't really mess that up.  Well, you can, but not here.  Consistently good.  Nice big serving/portions, and good mix of noodles, chicken (or shrimp), and green onions.  May be a bit heavy on the tofu, so if you don't like tofu have them relax a bit on it.

Then off to the Gai Ga Prow (Spicy minced port, or chicken with basil leaves and bell peppers).  Super good.  Not too spicy.

I typically order ala carte if I can, only because you get a bigger serving.  With the leftovers (and there will be leftovers as the portions are healthy), I order a side of rice and take it to go for lunch the next day.  In fact, I'm devouring my leftovers right now!  The only thing to note is that there is a bit of oil that is used in their cooking - so if you have a sensitive stomach, this could pose a bit of a problem.
author: Jason I.

description:
Funny how when we decide to eat on Castro Street we usually walk from Church to Market, up to 19th, then back to Market, then over to 18th, looking for dining inspiration along the way, then back to Castro, and again up to 19th where Thai House Express is located. It's come to be one of the "old reliable" restaurants where we usually end up eating. The next time we'll just go straight there and end the anticipation.

Good Thai food, the various vegetable dishes being our favorites. Nice varied menu with something for even the pickiest of eaters. 

See you there!
author: Mickey A.

description:
A decent Thai restaurant with a large menu selection.  For the most part it's standard Thai food that's a bit better than the average and  the prices are reasonable.  Their fried rice with shrimp and tomatoes is outstanding and the red, green curries and the egg plant (Ma Kuer) dish are fairly good.  Tom Yum Goong is also good, nicely sour and spicy.  The crispy tofu and mixed vegetable with peanut sauce was the only thing I've had there that's actually bad.  It was lettuce with peanut butter and tofu  I guess it's supposed to be similar to Gado Gado (Indonesian) but just tasted wrong.  

It's a good place for a quick bite and take out orders when you don't feel like cooking.  Service is generally pretty average to below average.
author: Paul K.

description: I went tonight and god the tofu with peanut sauce and the cucumber salad and a Thai iced tea.  It was delicious as always and the price is very good.  The staff is very nice also.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
I Love Love LOVE pumpkin curry and it was fabulous at Thai House Express! 

This place was hoppin for a Sunday night and as a group of 3, we were seated promptly. I devoured my pumpkin curry with chicken as my friends inhaled their chicken with cashews and green curry with tofu. I can vouch for their dishes too- everything was delish & cheap!
author: Chrissy L.

description:
The food is decent and don't expect it's better than the one on Larkin.   But If you wanted to have a decent Asian meal under $10 in the Castro, this is the place.

However, like so many reviewers here on Yelp, I do find the waiters there have plenty  of attitudes.  I have been going there since it was opened but recently I am reluctant to go there.

I do not feel welcome when the waiters there greet me with cold, motionless expressions.  When they came to the table, I could tell they didn't want to serve !  It's like they are doing me a favor.  The reason they could give attitude is that they are mostly busy all the time.  But hey, there are other choices in the Castro and they are not the only restaurant there.

Someone told me one of the waiters there got fired recently, actually it is good news ;-)  I hope they start learning who is the boss and paying for their salaries.  

With service like that, the business is doom to be failed and I hope the owner is reading all the reviews here and learn what needs to be improved.
author: Sfscubaman T.

description:
I am in very serious like with Thai House Express, but sadly have been held back from loving it by a number of issues. The food's preparation is authentic, but it often lacks spice and flavor.

The preparation is fairly authentic. As an example, I can always tell an Americanized Thai restaurant from an authentic Thai restaurant by their preparation of chicken kaprow, or stir-fried chicken with basil. Good (or not so good) Thai restaurants will use whole chicken breasts and cover them in basil and sauce. Better Thai restaurants will grind the meat into small pieces, and then cook. Rare is the restaurant that actually takes the time and effort at this extra step. Thai House Express is one of the few Thai restaurants in San Francisco that I've found that do this: so they automatically get some love.

But I cannot give this place many more accolades because I cannot, despite having eaten here at least 10 times, figure out how to ask them to make the food spicy. I have tried every trick in my spice-loving book. "Thai spicy" is met with an approving nod, yet bland results. "Very, very, very spicy" meets the same fate. Everything I have tried is met with the same bland response, and it is enervating. 

Although the food's preparation is right, I just want to know what I have to say to get flavorful food, and I'd gladly give this place five stars.
author: P Z.

description:
Decent service. 

Food was Ok to Good. We had the Pad Thai and the Yellow Curry Chicken.

The Pad Thai was better than I've tasted in a while, but I wouldn't say that its the best that I've ever tasted.

The Yellow Curry Chicken was OK too...

Restrooms are clean.

Thai iced tea didn't have much flavor.

All I remember is that my stomach was CHURNING and CHURNING a couple hours later.  I thought it was just me, until my husband told me that his stomach started to get upset as well.

I probably won't be coming here again. This restaurant isn't bad, but for some reason, my stomach churning experience will be associated with this restaurant.

Hope you have better luck....
author: A C.

description:
Yay I got sweet rice and mangoes! This never happens! And it was tender, and sweet and flavourful and like heaven. And I got thai iced tea.

I got heaven with a side of crack. 

mmmm!!!!
author: Lauren S.

description: I enjoyed this restaurant, mostly because of the busy gay atmosphere. The food was good. The Gaurdian says they have the best pad thai in the city, but I'm not so sure it was that amazing. The service was very quick and friendly.
author: Mark S.

description: Castro District, very friendly people a service. My sister was craving for Thai food. So we went to Thai House Express chicken pad Thai awesome.
author: Jay H.

description:
A group of 5 friends went to have a late Sunday dinner at this restaurant. We had little waiting time to get a table and the entire experience was ok.

HOWEVER, the reason I am giving them 1 start is because of a very SHADY business policy from the service staff. 

When we got our bill, everything was in Thai and we could not read it. The entire bill was 70US$. We added a 20% gratuity coming to a total of 85US$. Right before walking out of the table, one of our friends from Thailand took the bill and realized that tips were already included (on a party of 5). It seems, our bill was of 50$ but they added 40% on tips, making it 70$ and they do not mention it to us. 

Service staff was about to take a 35$ tips out of a 50$ bill. 

We would not mind if the service was particularly good, but it was NOT. 

This is a very SHADY policy and I wonder how many other customers have fallen for the same trick.
author: Luis G.

description: The food was just OK. The place had a slightly weird odor. The character inside wasn't terribly appealing. Meh.
author: Alexander J.

description:
Food was great. Tasted very fresh and was full of flavor. The prices were great too.

The waiter we had, however, was a bit of a diva. He acted as if he'd rather be anywhere but work. He also made a big deal when we asked for the check to be split.

Overall the food made up for his attitude.
author: kelly k.

description: Delicious Thai food! Great for take-out since the sit-down service is kind of slow (even when they're not busy), but the food tastes authentic and fresh. Best basil dishes.
author: Jennifer V.

description: Not good. With a group of 5 and none of us liked our food. I have been here before when visiting SanFrancisco and it was not good then either. Ate here out of convenience. Have eaten at several Thai restaurants in SanFran and not super impressed. Ate at Marnee Thai I think over a year ago and it was dreadful. I remember Lers Ros Thai being ok.
author: Try O.

description:
Enjoyed another wonderful lunch special - $9.95 for soup, salad, app, and an entree.  Not too crowded on a Monday for lunch - but out waitress seemed a bit in the weeds regardless.

Food - great
Service - could be better
Value - the best!!
author: Wayne C.

description: I'm not sure why, but I adore this place. They had me with the money bags and cucumber salad appetizer, but when they added the lunch special - YAY! Soup, salad, appetizer, entree... so good, so reasonable, and just the right portions for lunch. GO THERE TODAY!
author: Jeffrey H.

description:
Descent food.

HORRIBLE SERVICE. Overpriced. 

They charge for Diet Pepsi refills. 

Service is so bad that the goodness of the food is irrelevant. Despite being seated in the main traffic flow of the wait staff all drink glasses stayed empty. Worst of all, drink refills aren't free.

Too many Thai options to waste your time hiking up Castro Street for this place.
author: scott h.

description:
Marnee Thai will remain my favorite Thai place in SF, BUT since I live so close... I was SO HAPPY that this place is SO TASTY!

What also struck me is that almost every customer was a gay male... so, ladies... you may feel a bit out of place!  Straight boys... unless you are curious or comfortable with yourself, you may also feel like you're in the Twilight Zone.

ANYWAY... they have a GREAT menu and LUNCH SPECIALS that rock... hot food, waiters and hot customers!  I know there are several thai options in the hood, but this one stands above the rest from what everyone says.

I've never been unhappy with my food... my fav's are the pad kee mao and chan pad poo.  The soups are also great.

Boys, bring a friend or a date!  They do tend to get busy and often sport an impressive line, so beware of that.  Great people watching, too, with its copious window action.

OH and young coconut juice... mmm (but it's from a can, sadly.)
author: Aaron W.

description: Good place food quick, sit down Thai food. Service is generally fairly good and quick. I've been here many times and everything is quite consistent...occasionally a few items have been heavy with the salt but other than that no major issues. I have noticed that the food seems to taste better when eaten fresh at the restaurant rather than getting take out to bring home.
author: Kent W.

description:
Keeping it simple:

1.  Great Food
2.  Quick Service
3.  VERY Reasonably priced

Would definitely make this a regular if it wasn't over 3,000 miles away.

Terrific meal!
author: Paul G.

description:
I haven't eaten in the new location.  When this restaurant was on Noe, it was my favorite Thai restaurant and would have been given 5 stars.  Their Tom Ka Gai was perfection. This was the Tom Ka Gai by which all others would be judged.  I don't know if it still is.

The Salmon in a banana leaf was one of our standard orders because it was so good, and moist and flavorful.  The Gai Grapow and Gai Himmaparn were my other favorites. Their currys were wonderfully flavorful.

Looking at the new website, it looks like they've added quite a few things to the menu and screwed it up a bit too.  Instead of listing items under chicken, beef or seafood, they list them all under 'Rice dishes' which you can then order over rice, or ala carte (aka, without rice).  Ok, that's really stupid.  I can't find the Salmon wraped in a banana leaf.  Is it still there?  Is it listed under banana leaf dishes which I can now order with or without banana leaves?

To the webpage designer:
I'm not going to judge a restaurant on the quality of it's website, but what seriously bored, out-of-work, desperate, web-gadget freak designed this thing?  There is no need to use Flash.  Don't auto-load the tacky, hyper elevator-music.  All of the damn flashing, redrawing and resizing are annoying.  They do not, in any way, help the consumer.  
If you're trying to demo your design skills, the first thing I look for is, 'is the design appropriate for the product or service?'.  Yours is not.  This design is a mess which only serves to distract from the product rather than enhance or entice.
Just because you can, doesn't mean you should.  BTW, proofread before publishing...
author: Bill T.

description:
It was ok.

Nothing to write home about.  Lunch specials are a bargain for sure, but it was just ok.  

The Pad Kee Mao was standard, fat noodles, assorted veggies and such.  The dr.'s tofu/veggie dish was pretty standard too, both were lacking heat (spice) though.

Wished we had gone to Thailand Restaurant on Castro instead, but trying new things is a good idea every once in awhile.
author: Jen I.

description: I'm specifically a fan of the silver noodle soup and the sleepy shrimp. This place doesn't serve "American" size portions and can get a little pricey, but most of the food we've had is pretty dang good.
author: A.D. R.

description:
Better than the other Thai House Express!

They make a "Neur Kem" (Thai beef jerky) which is really delicious.  they take the beef into little pieces raw, marinate it in this lime pepper sauce, and deep fry it.  then served with this spicy light dipping sauce, mmmm so good.

Now, let's talk curry.  Curry should be neither sauce nor soup.  Curry should be fresh and have flavor in every bite, not just at the top or the bottom.  These guys do curry.  Green chicken curry rocks.  Fresh vegetables, served at a good hot temperature, and a nice kick of spice.  

Also, the service is pretty good.
author: E M.

description: The food was not bad but wasn't great or memorable in my opinion. And the rice was mushy and sticky, unlike what you would expect at other Asian restaurants. It tasted like when I make it at home! Based on that and the mostly poor customer service I would not recommend the place. The restaurant itself seemed dated and not clean. One of the booths in the rear had several slashes and duct tape on it when I came here. The server did not fully speak or understand English and got my order wrong. The cashier seemed bothered that I even I tell her this. Another employee then came out who was very accommodating, friendly, and was able to speak and understand English fluently and got the order right and adjusted the bill. Perhaps the cashier did not understand English either, I don't know.
author: L. A.

description:
Why do people rave about this place? There's zero authenticity here (ever take a peek in the kitchen?), the staff is rude (unlike authentic Thais), and the food is a bunch of boiled-over who-knows-what.

You want to impress your date? Open a can of Chef-Boyardee and light a candle-it's much more impressive.
author: S B.

description:
This place was good.  It wasn't fantastic, and it wasn't bad, it was just good.

I got the pad-ke-mao, and it wasn't that spicy, but I wanted it to be.  The price was decent.  I don't think it deserves $$.  I think $ is sufficient.
author: Terran O.

description:
Walked in at 8:30 on a Friday night and was seated rather quickly (under 10 minutes).  Service was quick and pleasant, and the server was more than happy to take a minute to answer our many questions about the food (for the record, "a la carte" just means a bigger portion).  I got a glass of wine and was impressed by how healthy a pour they offered.  My friend and I started off with the som tum papaya salad, which was delicious -- the spiciness was tailored just to my specifications, which I really appreciated.  I then had a bowl of the tom kha pak soup, which is basically a vegetarian verion of tom kha gai.  The balance of flavors was perfect, and the size of the portion was ideal for a light dinner (or a rather large appetizer, depending on your appetite).

We will definitely go back soon!
author: Laura R.

description:
Maybe I'm a little spoiled by living in the Sunset, right next to Marnee Thai. I found this place to be okay. Not horrible, but not fantastic. The prices were pretty nice on my wallet (on a budget) so I have no room to complain. Oh, the portions are huge. I couldn't even finish my plate. So it's good if you want a quick Thai fix in the Castro. 
The ambiance was very nice. However, the chairs were the most uncomfortable.
Minus two stars because it took them 30 minutes to give us our check (though they kept refilling our water glasses) after we asked for it.
author: Sharelle W.

description: I have never had a bad meal here. Even the times when they have gotten my takeout order mixed up and I get something I didnt order, its absolutely delicious! My favorite dishes are the duck fried rice and pad thai with seafood! The duck soup is pretty darn yummy!
author: David H.

description:
If you're adventurous enough to try something other than Pad Thai, order the Pla Pao (an excellent dish, when eaten with the accompanying green seafood sauce). Other good dishes that I've had here are the Goong Pad Prig and Gai Kaprow.

Enjoy...
author: Wes F.

description:
This isn't the best Thai food I've ever had.  And it certainly isn't the spiciest.  But goddamn if it isn't perfect in every other way.

For starters, it's the single closest restaurant to my house, sitting right on the corner of 19th and Castro.  Now this may not seem like something generally relevant to the Yelp population, seeing as how proximity to my house in the Castro does not translate to proximity to your house in Pacific Heights.  But first of all, fuck you and your $5mm mansion.  Second of all, if you think about it, $P(\textrm{you're near my house} | \textrm{you're reading this review}) \gt\gt P(\textrm{you're near my house})$.  Either you're looking for a place to eat in the Castro or you're reading my reviews through my social graph.  Either way, it's pretty clear that you proximity to MY house is pretty much YOUR #1 priority in picking a restaurant.

Second of all, it's open till 10:30 PM.  As you probably deduced from my little conditional probability reasoning, I'm an engineer.  This means I'm getting home from work after 10 quite often. 

Third of all, the menu's massive, but not in that intimidating 150-things-that-are-all-the-same stereotypical Thai place way.  I've had a few soups, which were pleasant to a fault -- of all faults to have, a decent one.  I've had some curries, which are a personal Thai favorite and have a good amount of range.  I'd recommend, though, the Thai House Specials: the Kao Ka Moo (stewed pork) and Kao Rad Na Gai Ha-yak (sauteed chicken) both featured very tender meat in a sauce that wasn't just your run-of-the-mill coconut milk + chiles.

Most important of all: price.  $7 (soup or "over rice" curry) and you get a delicious meal.  $9 ("a la carte": no rice, double the curry), and  -- if you can manage the difficulty of turning on a rice cooker for 20 minutes -- you have yourself a delicious meal plus delicious leftovers for lunch.  Either way, near my house (don't forget your #1 priority), that's a bargain.  In fact, my girlfriend and I split the leftover curry for lunch this afternoon.  This coming from someone who regularly eats 3000+ calories a day.  Feed me.  Thai food.
author: Jack S.

description: I'm pretty sure this is the best food in the world, thai or otherwise.  I first went here for a late dinner and it blew me away, it's well priced, close and clean inside.  I can't wait to go back!!
author: Ilia F.

description:
So far, this is my favorite Thai restaurant in SF! The food was just about as flavorful as I have been looking for in the city. The Pumpkin Curry was delicious and since this was my first time to ever have pumpkin curry, I'm excited to try it at some other Thai restaurants. My friend likes fried food, so we ordered crispy fried pork and it came out with a super thin and flakey crust and was just delish! The green papaya salad was not overly fish saucy which is good. And they serve STICKY RICE! I was so bummed that Marnee Thai doesn't serve it and sticky rice is usually my favorite part of eating thai food! For desert, we had taro balls in coconut milk. The balls were a lot like tiny mochi balls  and didn't have much flavor without the coconut milk. I did like it, but I doubt I will order it again. Besides, Hot Cookie is just down the street if you need something sweet after dinner. 

Try this place, it's really good!
author: Rex D.

description:
great job for seating our party of 25+ at the last minute, and chugging out food within 15 minutes of our arrival (even though the kitchen was on the verge of closing).

I ordered the papaya salad with salted crab--and I like the salty crab here better than the one they have at Osha Thai on Geary/Leavenworth.  I recommend they don't skimp on the shredded papaya and skip the wedge of napa cabbage.

good service.

(  |  )
author: Grace M.

description:
Very good chicken pad thai... they could be a little more consistent with the lime wedge and they should put some cilantro on top! 

Curries and stuff are very good as well, so is service!
author: Jim S.

description: Good tasting food, but sometimes a little oily.  Service is friendly and quick.  They have a great lunch special that is reasonably priced.
author: Avi G.

description:
Despite being one of the closer neighborhoods to me, my vision of the Castro's dining scene seems to be perpetually stuck on "brunch at Lime".  So I figured it was time to try to move beyond the stereotypes and get to know the Castro as just another (admittedly gentrified) nabe, via its everyday restaurants.  First stop: Thai House Express.

Turns out the spirit of Lime may be more pervasive around here than I thought.  Modern, white-n-black decor, suspiciously well-dressed & well-coiffed waitstaff...you get the idea.  What surprised me even more, though, are the dirt-cheap prices.  $6.95 for a hefty dinner entree over rice?  Not too shabby.  Tofu Pad King was pretty standard, but the Gai Ga-Prow (intensely spicy ground chicken) was altogether new to my palate, and delicious to boot.  Good job on the Thai Iced Tea too--very dark and deep taste that doesn't get lost in the sweetness.  Overall, I take Thai House Express as a sign that eating in the Castro can yet become a habit even for a decidedly un-fabulous straight man like myself.
author: Wes M.

description:
Last night after a 2.5 hour Aikido class in Noe Valley (see previous reviews) Edward and I decided to try Thai House Express on 19th and Castro only if there happened to be parking near the restaurant.  I fully expected to drive by and end up eating in the inner Richmond but there were actually a few open spots on Castro.  Sweet.  

Ambiance:
For a rather inexpensive restaurant, the place was very nicely decorated to look hip but also somewhat cozy.  In addition to views of Castro Street, there were tasteful paintings on the wall and low lighting.  

Food:
Portion sizes were good.  Sticky rice came in large, exceptionally sticky quantities and as a harsh critic of sticky rice, I give this order a 4.5 out of 5 (5 is reserved for the sticky rice at SEA restaurant in Brooklyn, the sweetest and stickies of all).
Everything was made veggie for us with none of the awkwardness that sometimes follows ordering a full veggie meal.  There was a corn fritter appetizer on the menu which was of large proportions and quite tasty.
The Tom Yum soup was good, not great.  About average and not spicy enough.  The Tofu and veggies were good and fresh, not too greasy, a definite plus.
***READ IF YOU ARE VEGGIE*** The curries are made with fish sauce, even the ones listed on the Vegetarian section of the menu.  I don't know why they did this but I am glad I asked.

Price:
Average for Thai in a cool neighborhood.  The total bill for two entrees, an appetizer and two orders of sticky rice came out to about $25.00.  And we were very full.

People:
Lots of nice looking guys in their mid-twenties to early thirties.  A crazy guy came in screaming and making a huge scene...entertainment, I guess.  The staff responded by pumping the electronica version of Snow Patrol's Chasing Cars louder...good response.
author: Valerie L.

description: My favorite Thai restaurant in the Castro.  I'm a big fan of Pad See Ew (hard to screw up) and their version doesn't disappoint.  Also to note, I'm not a big fan of eggplant but their Pad Ma-Kuer might just change my mind.
author: Sean H.

description:
This was the first place we went to when we got to San Fran. I was with my darling adorable immigrant parents (yeah it's cool I'm a commie too) and my brother (the only american out of the bunch). We had just driven down from Sacramento via Napa and Sonoma, and were all rather tipsy on phenomenal amounts of wine samples. We were staying on Gold Mine Hill, and went down to the Castro to find some dinner. Thai always works well, and we got a seat near the windows, which was a nice plus. We order and wait.

My mother, looking out window: "There are so many rainbow flags!"
My father: "What does the California flag look like? Maybe it's rainbow?"
(bear in mind we have lived in NYC for 17 years)
Me (trying to keep straight face): "It's the gay flag, guys."
My mother: 'There are gays in San Francisco?"
(my brother shoots his delicious tom kar gai out his nose)
Brother: Um, Ma, this is where gay came from.
My mother: "Wipe your face and don't be ridiculous. Gay came from everywhere."
Brother: "No, I mean like the gay rights movement and everything."
My dad, finally looking up and down Castro carefully: "I had no idea the west coast had gay people too!"
and so on and so forth.

But I digress.
The food was wonderful, and we had a great meal. Awesome curry, quick service, we were too stuffed for dessert (for my part, i wasn't interested in seeing green tea ice cream go up anyone's nose).

My family is infinitely amusing, but mostly for me.
author: Irene F.

description: Really good Pad Thai, and yummy Thai Iced tea, too!
author: Robert M.

description:
It's rare I'll write a dissenting review on Yelp but this time I've just gotta.


Dear Thai House Express on Castro,

Our "relationship" is OVER!

As you already know for the past six months I've wanted things to work out between us. But your food is lackluster and your service is downright dismal. Take for example last night when my friend and I came over to have a three-way with you. The front of the restaurant was already crowded and you refused to open up the back *ahem*. You sat us at a table for two right in front of the counter, in the thick of the dining orgy, than proceeded to treat us as if we were invisible for fifteen minutes. No water, no drink orders, not even a reach around. How rude!

When one of your waiters finally came over he was surly-- like he was coming off a bender or had gotten a little too much abuse that evening. We ordered up Garden Rolls, Pad Thai, Basil Chicken and Sticky Rice. It surprised me that he could even take our order considering he barely listened to anything we said. 

When our Garden Rolls came to the table, they were carried by a different server-- this one completely listless. He obviously didn't have the strength, or maybe just didn't have the desire, to place the platter all the way on our table. Now, it's been many years since I've waited a table but I'm pretty sure there's some unwritten rule about putting a platter all the way on the table, instead of letting half of it hang off the edge. Because, wonder of wonders, as soon as he took his hand off the platter, gravity kicked in, and it went crashing down to the floor. Not one of the other waiters came over to help clean it up. So it took our listless server a good three minutes to get everything up off the floor-- with nary an apology mind you.

Imagine our surprise when a new platter came out only thirty-seconds after the broken platter had been taken away. This time it was placed three-quarters of the way on our table. I can't be sure if you just reused the same garden rolls that were on the floor but I have a suspicion you did. BTW- the rolls were so dry we choked, and we're gay so choking is something we rarely do. Thai House Express on Castro-- if you're going to pre-make "fresh" garden rolls, the least you can do is drape them with damp paper toweling so they don't dry out. That's my Martha Stewart Good Thing(tm) tip to you-- you're welcome in advance.

Can you answer me a question? When did your Pad Thai become synonymous with fish flavored candy? After our first bite both my friend and I became diabetic. And the Basil Chicken-- EESHK! It was so salty even the other people in the restaurant who didn't eat it will be retaining water for the next month. I will admit that the Sticky Rice came out alright-- which surprised me since you seemed to eff everything else up.

Thai House Express on Castro-- we won't see each other any more. I am not going to mall dodge you, instead when I pass by your front or side I'll flip you off because I'm hurt and I don't feel the need to curtail any impulses.
author: Eric B.

description:
I go to the Thai House on Larkin just because I am used to that one. I finally had the chance to try out this place today. The ambiance and decor are definitely MUCH better then the one on Larkin. However, they do charge $1-$2 more for the dishes  which I didn't mind too much since it was very comfortable dining there. Here's what my date and I ordered:

Appetizer: Hot and sour soup with shrimp (ask for spicy if you are up for the challenge. It was very tasty and on a cold night like this it really hit the spot)
Entree: Dungeness crab noodles (it reminds me of Pad Thai. Not bad)
Desert: Mango with sticky rice (standard.. wished it was served warmer)
author: Ervinna L.

description: Whenever I go to my BFF's place in the Castro, I insist on getting takeout kao soy from Thai House Express. He swoons over the pad thai and swears it's the best he's ever had, but I love my curry noodles so much that I can't imagine ordering anything else.  My finicky preschooler makes quick work of the vegetarian egg rolls. I just wish they offered delivery. I mean, come on...they even have the word "express" in their name; express that food to my doorstep, please!
author: Valeria R.

description:
Thai House is exceptional...

The reason it's so good is their "Thai houses specialties".  You'll find it in the center of the menu.  The dishes found in this section are specialty dishes that I haven't been able to find at other Thai eateries.  They offer Khao Mun Gai,, Khao Ka Moo, Khao Pad pla Kem etc. These dishes are all served over rice, and are generally considered lunch dishes in Thailand. They also offer Khao Soy, a curried noodle dish which is a specialty dish from northern Thailand. If you're tired of having the ubiquitous Phad Thai and Tom Yum goong, I recommend you try some of the dishes from the "specials" menu, you won't be disappointed.
author: Nopadon W.

description: The food was okay. Quick and friendly service.
author: Marck N.

description:
So we are here far too often for me to give it a negative review, like once every 6 weeks, maybe more.  

The food is good.  The eggplant dish is delicious.  Sometimes, when the restaurant isn't crazy busy the kitchen gets creative in its presentation.  This is nice.  Yet none of the dishes ever really packs a punch.

The praram pak has far too many vegetables.   Please limit it to spinach because if that's what I am in the mood for, I don't go here, its just not that good.

The staff is always pleasant but oh so forgetful.  Like all the time, something Always goes wrong.  They are always like half sorry about it too.  It's become a running joke and someone always says "remember the service here is just not that good" and we all laugh about the time they like did not bring out so and so's food or the "more rice" or "2nd thai ice tea" that never arrived.
author: Sean S.

description:
Let me show you how I tend to pray:
OMG my effing lips!
OMG my effing lips are on FIRE!
OMG my effing lips are on 5 alarm FIRE and my stomach may be joining them in infamy!
OMG please, please don't let me puke in the street. 
OMG please, please don't let me puke in the street before I get the two blocks home.
OMG that Tom Kha Gai soup was such a bad/good choice that I'm totes doing penance for sinfully ordering it spicy.
OMG I have mocked you because I'm NOT Thai. The only "Asian" I am is Caucasian and it is my fault for exhibiting bravado. 
OMG I am truly in hell and it cost me $14, including tip, cuz I also had a side of Jasmine Rice and a Thai Iced Tea.
OMG please, please let my two lips burning on my face not indicate another two lips that will burn in the morning and are located elsewhere.

Amen.
author: Jill D.

description:
I ordered Pat Kapow and Som Tum, although I really wanted Kao Mun Gai, but they only had crappy regular rice, which even our server said wasn't good.

The Som Tum was pretty mild, I would've preferred much stronger flavors both sweet and sour and spicy. The Pat Kapow was good, but their rice is pretty awful. I also forgot to add a fried egg, but that wouldn't have made up for the bad quality rice. I know I sound like I'm making a big deal about nothing, but seriously, RICE, that is like one of the most essential parts of Thai food, if you can't get that right then you've got serious problems.
author: Dennis C.

description:
Waitress: What would you like?
Husband: Chicken Larb, please.
Waitress: How spicy?
Husband: VERY spicy.
Waitress: pause, VERY spicy?
Husband : Yes, VERY spicy.

Larb arrives and I serve myself a small portion. Took one bite and my
head nearly exploded. Hottest Larb I have ever had in my life but still 
very good cause I DO LIKE SPICY. I keep all my comments and bulging eyes cast aside cause I don't want to give away the secret as to what he has just ordered and had delivered to our table. The first bite he takes I hear, "Holy Fuck, what did I order". We each sweat through
2 small servings and the other items arrive at the table so we can take a breather from one of the hottest dishes I've ever eaten.  We 
took the leftovers home and watched a friend suffer through the balance. I will definitely return to Thai House Express and try many of the other yummy looking items on their menu but I won't be ordering VERY spicy. I think Medium  will do just fine cause they do mean business with the VERY spicy.
author: Cindy J.

description:
I've tried this place twice -- the first time I arrived at 10:00 and the hostess rushed us to order (saying we had 5 minutes) then came back 2 minutes later and told us we had to order "right away". My date and I said screw it and left. This was annoying because the stated time of closing is: 10:30, I wish that restaurants could be less ambiguous about their closing times and just state when they stop serving food. 

On our second attempt, we were smashed into the table by the door and I practically had people _crouching_ over my food while waiting to be seated. Even worse was that they had to shout to each other as the euro-crap techno was blasting through the air. The food was tasty and reasonably priced. Probably about three stars a piece but the ambiance really drained me (and my rating).
author: Ralph G.

description:
I'm not a fan of Thai food. I don't like peanut oil, peanut sauce, coconut mixed or attached to any food, or curry. So when it comes to choosing a place to eat, Thai is never on my list.

Fortunate for me, 3 of the 5 most recent dinner dates have insisted on their favorite Thai restaurants. I know, I have the best luck. Last night was Thai House Express (THX) on Castro.

So I was standing on the corner of 19th & Castro waiting for my date to arrive and thinking of the nearest pizza slice, when a Yellow Cab arrived and the most amazing legs stepped out of the car and took my hand. I quickly went dumb and forgot everything I learned in fourth grade. The night chill had started to roll in so we retreated inside THX for warmth and food. We were seated immediately. I like that kind of service. 

The decor was simple yet nice... the crowd was mostly men but not intimidating... and sitting across from me were a pair of beautiful blue eyes and a gorgeous smile... My overall impression, Warm and Safe.

After several attempts from our server we finally decided on "Something-something Basil with Chicken", "Blah blah Blah Red Curry with Beef", and brown rice. Did I get the Thai Iced Tea?
