Of course I had the ice tea. It is the only thing I anticipate from a Thai eatery! I have a bit of a sweet tooth.

Our food arrived in typical white bowls found in every contemporary Asian-Style restaurant. The presentation was great! I was all about it, even though I had to find my own chop sticks. The "Something-something Basil" was good. Through my recent Thai experiences, I've discovered the one Thai dish that won't make me vomit. 

But Oh that "Blah blah Blah Red Curry!" It was amazing and I hate curry! I had to stop myself from picking up the dish and drinking the sauce directly from the bowl. Although I did pour the sauce all over my "Something-something Basil" which turned into a lovely combo in my mouth. 
I'll consider myself a fan of  THX especially when it comes to "Blah blah Blah Red Curry". I mean, this stuff was really good and on top of that, my date ended well. 
I even got a little tongue action before heading to the Mission to meet the boys at the bar.
author: Tobias W.

description:
Gay men and Thai food. Who knew this combo would work so well together?

I'm a pad thai fanatic--a good standard to compare Thai restaurants, I say--and the pad thai here wasn't bad at all. Quite good.

However, the service here can be sloooow--but at least they weren't rude. It must've been a busy night. I felt sorry for the pretty gay men crowded by the door, looking longingly at our noodles and Thai iced teas.

Ok, not really. Muahahah.
author: Richie K.

description: Thai House Express has saved me a few times from decision fatigue. It's location makes it a easy choice and the food never disappoints.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
If only the Castro had more restaurants like this, people wouldnt be complaining about the wait so much! Went tonight at rush hour Friday dining after a quick happy hour and the wait was just 5 mins!

I for one have always had a GREAT experience with the food (except when I got ahead of myself and ordered #24 a litttttle too spicy...my bad.) the service and the location.  My friend always comments on this one waiter he has the biggest crush on.  I try not to focus on it too much (OK, who am I kidding, there is this one that is super HOT, but thats besides the point..)

Thai can be so dime a dozen now, but you can definitely tell they do it right with the food and extensive menu.  AND they have brown rice.  

Try the pork stew dish over rice with special sauce or the gang dang (no, not gang bang) curry.  Be daring with spicy but if new say you want it mild because they will throw on the heat.
author: Michael K.

description:
service was neglectful, despite being nearly empty.

ordered the catfish, the waitress explained they don't stock catfish anymore.
ordered the drunken noodles, they were out of flat noodles.

ordered the sukiyaki....it was vile.
had the the coconut soup, very good.
also, the house beef dish, also very good.

i remember eating some really good thai food here years ago. i'm assuming it has changed hands since then.
author: Flix N.

description: A friend who lives nearby brought me here for a nice dinner.  I had the catfish dish, which was absolutely fantastic.  We were there early, so didn't have any trouble getting a table, but they get pretty crowded later because it's a pretty small place.  Well worth a visit.
author: Cassidy P.

description:
I can't believe I haven't reviewed this place yet. I love this restaurant - it is as reliable as your favorite furry friend who comes to greet you at the door every day when you come home from work. 

Delicious every time, no matter what you order. Whenever I'm in the Castro and don't know where to go, I always default to Thai House Express, and I am always glad I made that decision.
author: Michelle G.

description:
I think this place is great. Prices are good, and the taste is right.

I had the Tom Yum noodle soup at a level 5 spicy. I can handle spicy food, but damn, that level 5 spicy burned my bowels. Stick with a 2 or 3. Is there a Thai version of Montezuma's revenge? Maybe Sukhothai's Return Mak Mak?

Service was attentive as I was hailing down the waiter for more water to douse the fire going on in my mouth.

Try to get a corner table. Its a great place to people watch while eating some tasty Thai food.
author: Rocky K.

description: Especially enjoyed the sautéed eggplant and pineapple fried rice tonight. The food is pretty decent here overall. Not the most personable wait staff, however. I've come here a couple times for lunch to get food to go, and haven't been disappointed.
author: Len M.

description:
I was wary when my friend took me here. Firstly,most places in SF are hugely expensive for what they serve, and usually over-hyped.
Still, I decided to keep my mind open. Their menu looked decent - even decent prices.
I asked them what kind of meat they used in their eggplant chicken: the server immediately said "Only breast meat, and free range, organic-fed chicken"

Need I say more: I was hooked.
Our meal was delicious, and yes, the chicken was excellent.
We got their fresh spring rolls as an appetizer, and it was so good!!
I liked this place a lot. Service was good. They filled our water, and didn't bother us, but were there promptly when we needed them.

Because of their quality of meat (to me, that's a restaurant that cares about food they feed their patrons), I give them a 5 stars
author: Shilpi D.

description:
Imagine my excitement when I found out that my favorite Thai restaurant (http://www.yelp.com/biz/vKBW6SWFrIYXW1kIOFY_Ng) was opening a new location on Castro Street! Best Thai food, and a crowd of gay boys too?! What else do you really need?

The food is very similar to that at the original location, think: delicious authentic Thai, at ridiculously low prices... amazing! And yes, the crowd mostly consists of Castro gay boys, tank tops and Diesel jeans aplenty, eye candy galore... But the place is a little small, so the wait on weekends can be prohibitive. Nevertheless, probably one of the best dinner options in the Castro.
author: David S.

description:
I'm surprised to know that this is the second place that makes thai styled yellow curry chicken the way it's suppose to be- tender dark meat, coconut milk,  and full of flavor. The other place is "Manora Thai." My friend and I had the shrimp hot sour soup, the yellow curry chicken, and the special Pan fried noodle crab dish. All of these dishes were well cooked and the portions were very generous. 

The decor was simple and clean. I peaked into the kitchen on the way to the restroom and it looked clean as well. You know what they say about a clean kitchen! 

Seating didn't seem too much of a problem since we got there about 645pm. About 730pm, more people and bigger parties started coming in.
author: Bert T.

description:
Me & the wife eat here all the time, and we've never had a bad experience. The menu is broad enough that there's something for anyone's tastes, and the food is really really delicious. A bit posh-looking, too -- we thought with "express" in the title it would be greasy, but it's really well-crafted food. Cheap, too. We're always like, "I can't believe how much good food we're getting for so little money."
Nice decor, nice crowd, nice staff. Sometimes the wait to get a table is a bit long, but always worth it. Be careful with the spicy dishes, because they're not shy.
Once, we were eating dinner and a big party broke out into "Happy Birthday," but it wasn't like a normal restaurant-birthday-singing ... it was like some crazy 8-part harmonized choral hymn. What a nifty place.
author: Matt B.

description:
I completely agree with Candice on Kao Ka Moo. But those were not pickled gai lan. Sorry. They were pickled dry bok choi. And I have no problem finishing the whole fracking dish. I weigh 145lb and I am 5'9". CERTAINLY NOT a dish to share. I may have lived in Singapore for a year too long but this dish is not spicy to me. I always ask for more of the spicy sauce . . . 

I've been going to Thai House Express on Castro for 3 years and I NEVER order anything else. The times when my friends ordered something other than KKM, they were always disastrous. 5 stars for KKM.

I have written on the bill, "Here's a penny that your service deserves". One of the waitress (tonight) took the condiment tray away from our table 5 seconds after our dishes were set on our table. When asked, she said "I am cleaning them" I went "Clean them AFTER I finish eating then".
author: DANIEL T.

description:
This Thai place is so damn popular, most likely due to its location. Mediocre service and average Thai food wouldn't normally attract a big dinner crowd, but whatever, this is San Francisco! 

I hit this place at least twice per week, because it is the closest restaurant to my house. I guess I could simply walk another half a block to widen my choices, but meeeh, I've found the silver noodle soup to my liking. 

Yes, about the soul-soothing silver noodle soup:  If you happen to be dealing with any sort of digestive issues, come to Thaihouse Express and try this soup. For the love of everything holy, this soup does a better job a clearing up digestive problems than a room-ful of Kaiser physicians.  Yeah I'm exaggerating a little, but therein lies the tonic to cure diarrhea and dysentery.

Fun activity: If you're ever walking past this restaurant, peer into the window at the 2-person table.  95% of the time, you'll see an Asian guy and an older white guy.  19 out of 20 times!  ;)
author: Daniel C.

description:
My roommate and I eat at Thai House Express once every couple of weeks but if it were up to us, it would be much more often. We don't usually have to look at the Menu because we already have our favorites picked out, which are the Sauteed Eggplant and Red Curry with Chicken.

The seating and service is quick and the quality is great for this price range.  Its hard for me to eat at any other Thai place and not compare the price vs. quality to Thai House. 

note: They have brown rice and its delicious!
author: Shannon A.

description:
My go-to place for Thai food in the Castro.  Good service, OK food. I always order too much so I have left overs the next day.

If you order the Basil Beef, be prepared for a pile of ground beef mixed with some basil. Not terribly inspiring.
author: Don m.

description:
I live a block away.  We have them on speed dial.  They say 15 minutes for takeout, they mean 10.

The food is great.  What you sacrifice in not being able to substitute (ie red curry is always beef), you gain in efficiency and TASTE.  Having spent months in Thailand, this is certainly one of the most authentic restaurants in recent memory.  The spicings are spot-on, the dishes well prepared and the staff nothing short of super friendly.
author: Aaron G.

description:
Horrific pad thai.  I picked some up last night 1/30/07 and was sooooooo dissappointed!  The pad thai looked and tasted like it was a day old.

I also ordered beef in a red curry sauce and it was bland bland bland.  

Only thing good was the sticky rice.  

Maybe cuz I am farang I got the bad stuff and thought I wouldn't notice???
author: Yelper H.

description:
I'm gonna keep it to you real - that's my middle name, right? Yeah...it is.

If you are hungry, and you want food now - not like "Oh, I can wait...so no worries..." but are like, "GIVE ME SOMETHING TO EAT" then perhaps this might not be the place for you. I'm just saying...

But the food is good. I mean, you want some tasty Thai, then do it. It's been in the Castro for a bit, so you can't really go wrong with a place that has survived all the other restaurants, right?

I've ordered many of the items on the menu, and find that everything has been good or great, no problem. 

My only thing is that they can sometimes be slow to clean up tables and clear them for customers waiting, and a few times I've sat there and sipped my water oh-so-patiently waiting for someone to finally come take my order. I even put on the puppy dog eyes that say "Please sir, may I place my order now?"

It's a good place, but be careful - watch the crowd and see how long it might take you.
author: Nicolas H.

description:
Friendly, fun, and they have this whole fish -- I think it's the Pla Sam Ros -- that has a sweet and spicy sauce over it that's excellent. My mom still speaks a little Thai from when we lived there and the staff eats his up.

Recommended.
author: Karsten P.

description:
Having pecked around the Castro's gastronomical dry pastures for a while, I tend to be rather cautious about spending my preciously earned dollars in this neighborhood. One would think that the homosexual population with its stylish manners and delicate views on what's in and what's not would be more demanding on both the variety and the quality of the restaurants in their very own territories, but no, that tends not to be the case; the Castro, overall, offers mediocre and uncreative menus, with little or no imagination, not only that, but the quality of the actual ingredients in some of the local establishments can be almost shockingly abysmal. Perhaps more importance is given to 'be seen' eaten here, rather than to what one is actually eating, personally that's what I think has happened over the years, resulting in badly trained restaurants, with non-dynamic chefs and menus. 

After my partner's fund-raiser event, we walked back home and were simply too tired to cook, an activity we throughly enjoy, we therefore decided to try out this place which always seems rather busy, to our surprise the food was quite good, presentation and more importantly quality and flavours; both appetizers and main courses were quite delicious, the veggies crisply fresh and the wine not bad at all. 

Perhaps the only negative point was the service, a rather abrupt and perhaps rude little Tintin-wannabe waiter with a t-shirt perhaps too tight for serving; however the issue was readily sorted when a tired and perhaps annoyed 'me' told him to smile and to get on with his job, the poor lad did improve and we decided to leave him a generous tip; you simply have to teach people. 

Good place, def simple and delicious and very affordable.
author: Adam B.

description: I ordered the yellow curry chicken and there was all kinds of chicken fat and  inedible parts of chicken in it. Two stars for well cooked rice and yellow curry i could put on top of the rice with the potatoes. Server was nice and friendly also.
author: Chris D.

description: Good Thai Food.  I was really hungry and got the Green Curry and the portion was a little bit too small for me so I ordered a second plate, this time Pad Thai, and it was awesome and I was super full.
author: Joel G.

description:
I will have to venture out and say that this place is probably in the top 3 of Thai places in the city!  My best friend and I use to hit up this place all the time (because he lived in the neighborhood).  Also, my happy hour group use to take over the place after drinks all the time.  There's nothing like Thai food to rejuvenate you after too much drinking!

Usually the wait isn't too bad and the service is really fast.  I'm not a huge fan of the Thai iced tea but hey, there's always Singha.  The pad thai is adequate and my favorite is the beef stew.

Yummy food + little $$$ = lots and lots of food!   Great fun to go in a group!  Can't wait to go again and get the beef soup..yum!
author: Myko L.

description:
YUMMMY.

Pad thai with beef.  Not much beef but the flavor was soo damn yummy I forgot what I was missing.

Also fried egg rolls.  DEElicious, as my 2 year old goddaughter likes to say!  

Fast fast To Go service too so if you have a minute to call, you can be eating literally in 10 minutes.

I am saving the menu on my desk.
author: Denise B.

description:
I'm a yelp stalker but work procrastination has turned me into an actual participant today.  First review has to go to the restaurant I frequent most...Thai House Express!!

I can't speak to the other ones in the city, but this one has the best thai food around.  

Stars for:

*Fresh Food-Fast -- everything comes piping hot and super fresh

*Healthy for the picky people -- we always ask for "lessLess oil and they're more than happy to oblige

*Best in the neighborhood --- with four nearby thai choices (2 have gone under in the past year or so), you know this place is good

*Friendly staff --- with the exception of the sometimes cranky waitress, they're all really nice folks.  And chances are you'd catch me cranky sometimes if you saw me twice a week.  That's how often I go here.

*Did I mention it's fast and fresh and healthy?  That's an unusual Thai food Trifecta

Hooray for Yelp!
author: Pink ..

description:
It was alright.
I know i know, im very picky about my Thai food. This place was tasty. But standard. I just wish they could have packed a bit more punch (and heat?) into the food! The salmon wrapped in banana leaf is the only item that saved this place from 3 stars. That and the fact that the service was good, the decor nice, and they sat my friend at her table even though the rest of us were still searching for parking.
author: Mollie M.

description:
Nice people, Excellent food.  Mike you picked an awful dish...but jimmy and I got the best ever thai dishes...i must admit.  

Mileu:
loud, stuffy, I don't think there were any women there.  I think I was in the castro.....

Service:
Nice, they gave my friends and I a seat ASAP

Food:
EXCELLENT.  I will be back....i forgot what I ate, but it was very good.  Better than any place in the city I've been to
author: M L.

description:
I have a problem when it comes to Thai food. I am such a Pad Thai fanatic that it takes me a long time to order something else on the menu. I have to be sick to death of their Pad Thai before I wander to something else,  and if there are more Thai restaurants around I'd rather go try their Pad Thai then order something else at my favorite restaurant. There are so many f'n Thai restaurants near me that I fear I will never taste anything else. It's sad really, but Pad Thai is also my litmus test for a Thai restaurant, so what are ya gonna do? If a place can't get that right then I move on.

The current bar for me was set at Manivanh in the Mission. Alas, they were closed today so I started yelping to see if I could find a new target. I decided to try Thai House Express and by now you know wtf I ordered. 

All I have to say is Daaaaaiiiiiimmmm! I just shoveled a pad thai of EXTREME quality into my gullet. Now I think the bar might have been raised again. So much so that it prompted me to type this up. 

Hmm....  It's really close though. I may have to go back to Manivanh to make sure. Maybe I'll do some tests in my lab this week. ;-)
author: Gabe M.

description:
Thai House Express is our go-to spot for Thai when we need takeout. We used to dine in there all the time, but haven't been back since our son was born. The service is always fantastic, orders are ready in 10 minutes from our call. Portions are huge: we get three dishes & rice, and have enough for two or more meals for our family of three.

Staples from their menu in our household: 

Gai Ga Prow - the minced chicken. Everyone in our house loves this dish, including our 2.5 year old son.

Gang Khew - Wan - the green curry, with tofu. Crisp veggies, tasty curry.

Gang Panang Nuer - red curry & beef. Beef that is soft, and delicious.

We used to get their Pad Thai, and burned out on it. Either it got worse, or we simply got over it. We eat Thai House Express at least once every three weeks for the past three years, and have yet to have a bad experience with them.
author: Greg Q.

description:
This is the only Thai place I've found in SF where I have an mmm-mmmm experience every time.  Everywhere else I've been in the city for Thai seems to be missing something - I'm not sure if it is a fear of fish sauce...it is probably something I probably just shouldn't ask too many questions about and just shut up and be grateful that I've found a place that takes care of my craving and not think too hard about it...

Favorites here: 
 - Chicken Satay
- Green curry 
- Pad Kee Mao
- Tom Kha Gai
- Kao Pad Pak
 - Pad See Ew
- Pumpkin Curry

This is the place when we are tired, want something good to eat and don't feel like cooking that we look at each other and simultaneously suggest and know that we're both interested...
author: Maria C.

description:
Mmmmm... It is soooo goood! I did not have a single mediocre dish at this place. The rolls, noodle dishes, veggie goodies. 

Great location. Friendly staff. Reasonable prices. And icing on the cake: cute local boys :)))

I should also mention the sinfully delicious coconut juice: you will get a quick caramel high!!! Liquid dessert!

What more do you want people? Come on already...

PS. The one on Larkin looks a bit more authentic but they are both equally good!
author: Oz O.

description: Decent food and decor, and good location.  The big turn-off?  A little army of androgynous skinny-a$$ Asians running around serving food.  Even David Beckham would feel fat dining here, which would not translate into good appetite.  Nevermind the fact that my boyfriend and his band of fellow Asian-enthusiasts consider this "dinner with a show."  Pick your own poison, boys.
author: Peter C.

description: Delish! One of the best places for Thai that I've been to! When you ask for spicy, you get spicy! ;)  Friendly service too.  Definitely recommend this place!
author: Chich S.

description:
Great place. Very quick, especially for take out. Food is consistent and yummy.

Try anything on the "specials" menu. My favorites: Pla sam ros (red snapper in sweet/spicy sauce), and the Corn Cakes. Yum!
author: Dick C.

description: Crab pad Thai delivers,but to change for soda refills..annoying!
author: James B.

description:
Have been going here since they opened - lots of choices from the menu to choose from - curries, soups, rice dishes, noodles, you name it!  Service is excellent and prompt, and the food is yummy.  I have never had a bad meal here.  I also like the design of the place very crisp, modern and clean.  You can always tell the better restaurants by how nice their restrooms are...Thai House's is very clean and modern.

I recommend some of their lesser known pork and beef dishes with rice.  The spicy beef will set your taste buds on fire if you like spicy! Khorb koon!!!
author: Tiberius A.

description:
I got lunch here one day while I was in the city and shared two meals with my friend.  The green curry with tofu was very good.  I asked the server to make it spicy and my dish actually had some heat!  The pad thai was pretty standard.  Good thai iced tea too. 

The place has a clean, contemporary design and was a nice little place to grab lunch.
author: Megan D.

description:
We've been here many times, and it's pretty consistent. Small portions that account for the reasonable prices, unfriendly waitstaff, and NO REFILLS ON SODA "OR" REGULAR ICED TEA!! I've never heard of such a thing with Iced Tea... thats why you order it, so you can quench your thirst again and again! I can understand Thai Iced Tea without refills, and "sometimes soda" being a one time deal, but NOT Iced Tea. The portions as I mentioned are small. For $30 for two with no booze, you shouldn't still be hungry. 
What is with the staff there? Don't they read these reviews? Someone should print them out and leave them with the owner/manager. It is such a waste to have a good place with decent food, and rude staff, and leave thirsty and hungry.
author: Mark T.

description: I've only eaten here once but was that once a great experience. I am not sure what the name is of the appetizer that I ate, I just know the item looked like a small money bag.... it was filled with tasty chicken and was so tasty! I would hit this spot again just for that item.   I also had the pad thai... and it was very good.  Everyone at my table enjoyed his/her dish. Its a solid spot for Thai.... check it out!
author: David C.

description:
quick and convenient.  but there's much better thai closer to market on castro.

however, if you want a fast sit down and run out.  this place is good for that.  much like a macdonald's.

the see-and-be-seen factor in this place is fantastic.  which is cool if you're cruising.  otherwise that much cruising is distracting.
author: Peter K.

description:
UPDATED: Yummy! And cheap! But my GOSH the service is slow. Usually it's bearable, but most recently: 6 people went out to dinner. 2 were served. 20 minutes later, another 3 got their dishes. FINALLY 15 minutes after that, I was granted the opportunity to eat. 
Does anyone else believe that service sometimes sucks when gratuity is automatically added to the bill (because the party size is greater than 5, or whatever the rule is)? 
Anyway. I love the food here, and the prices. But it's hard to go back when they were so slow, and unapologetic. Who knows, maybe it's the football on tv in the kitchen. I'm not one to speculate, but I am bitter, and that's where you come in, Yelp.
author: Anika K.

description:
Whenever I write a review I account for value. If a meal is $40+ a plate, the dining experience should knock my socks off. If the meal is $5, welllll... I'll let some things slide.

I mention this because Thai House Express' dishes are pretty inexpensive and you get a quality meal for your money. The last time I visited, we had a party of 4. We ordered 4 entrees and 2 appetizers (no drinks) and it broke down to less than $15 per person including tip. The food was very tasty & the service was attentive and cordial. The menu offers over 100 food selections, the atmosphere is modern, clean and a bit austere. This is a solid restaurant that serves good food at very affordable prices.
author: Kevan M.

description:
The pad thai here is my favorite in the city, so far. Beef curry tasty. Duck dish, good as well, albeit a bit fatty. 

Bonus: I always run into friends there, trying to refresh post Sunday in the 'stro.
author: Nikke G.

description:
Ate here last night. It was technically a date, though I think we're quickly becoming just friends. Which is actually very nice.

I got here before my date did, and had the pleasure of choosing between the table by the door (drafty, cold) or the table by the kitchen (clanging, bright). I chose the latter; at least it was a large booth.

The food was whelming. Not under- or over-; just whelming. They asked me how spicy I wanted my Cru Plaid Poo (or whatever the noodles with crab meat was called): I always take the middle ground on a first try, so I asked for the middle ground. My date ordered the green curry, spicy: she was in a mood to damage her tastebuds.

Turns out, my dish had a creeping bite that made me break a sweat (OK, granted, not hard to do; I love spicy foods, but in truth I'm physically a spice-wuss). Turns out, the green curry was milder. We shared.

The rest was fairly standard Thai restuarant experience. The food was good. Nothing to write home about (I'm only writing this review because (a) the place is fresh in my memory, (b) I needed to write more reviews, (c) I wanted to demonstrate that I have a social life and go on real dates, and (d) I wanted to subtly hint that I am looking for new friends who will go to new restaurants with me).
author: Zak N.

description:
To be honest the food is not that great but it has great vibe and that's why I have been there dozens of times and i will go there again. Their noodle dishes are good and cheap and w/ $20 you can feed two people and enjoy the hustle and bustle.

overall it is a cool cheap eat.
author: Lo F.

description:
I have been here a few times after hitting the bars and the dishes that I ordered were always YUMMY. I love their noodle soup dish. It is very delicious.

One dish to avoid is anything with duck in it. Their duck is mostly fat.

The service is nice and friendly. I always come with a big group and we have yet to wait for a table. They are nice and friendly, and put up with our behaviors.

FYI I have always ate here with alcohol in my system, so that might affect my taste buds.
author: Chatree T.

description:
My impressions of the place was promising at first, on a slow wednesday night. I felt comfortable the prices looked good. I got my food and things started to stray. I asked for spicy and I didn't taste a pepper of it. My coffee was forgotten, and my RAD NA PAK, was baseless in taste, the rice quite plain and too dry (no brown rice option)

The atmosphere is enjoyable, i could see ordering drinks for awhile being a fun day/night. I think the place sees opportunities for improvement, but this is not at all a bad place to try out.
author: Ricky V.

description:
we get to go food here at least once, sometimes twice per week. They know us by name and what we usually order. It's consistently delicous, fairly priced and the take good care of us.

My partner loves the green curry chicken (xtra spicy) with steamed brown rice. I enjoy the corn cake appetizer, the yellow mustardy chicken curry on egg noodles with red onion and a type of thai pickles...delicious.

My favorite dish there is their Pumpkin Chicken Curry. To die for.! Seriously over the top delicious....

Thanks for taking such good care of us guys. Steve and Johnny
author: Johnny G.

description: Had the duck over rice which was so so. Felt there was more skin and fat vs actual meat. On the other hand, fried rice and Thai ice tea was really good.
author: David R.

description:
My partner and I seem to keep making the drive over to the Castro just for the great food at Thai House Express.  Everything we have order has been great- our personal hit list is as follows:
1.Tom Kha Gai Soup- soooo good!
2.Corn Cake- trust me just try them
3. Ga-Prow- I had the chicken and it was great but I really want the beef!
4. Pla Sam Rod- Tasty catfish.
5. Pineapple Fried Rice- yum.
6. Pad Se-Ew- Love the beef.
7.Thai House Beef- the sauce is dynamite - really hot but so good.
We always get great service.
author: Brian C.

description:
They've started a lunch special that is more food than you need for cheap! 

Seriously: best damn thai. I could eat this morning, noon, nite. If you want SPICY they GIVE IT.

Even Picky Eater Jim finds a food to two he loves.
author: Rose J.

description:
This place was delicious and the prices were amazing! I am so used to SF restaurants being expensive so I was really happy looking at the prices on the menu.  The portions are really great for family-style eating (for like, 3 people or so), and my two friends and I split three entrees (that coconut milk soup (forgot the name), red chicken curry, and pad kee mao) and one appetizer (veggie spring rolls).  

The food around us smelled delicious and when we got the food, it definitely lived up to the wonderful aromas.  Each dish was soooo flavorful and especially the soup was a surprisingly tasty treat (whodda thunk that coconut could be savory??) 

Because the prices were great, I wasn't expecting the presentation to be nice or the portions to be huge, however they were very nicely presented on pretty white plating worthy of more expensive restaurants.  

I guess the reason it doesn't get 5 stars is because the decor is a little cheesy.  I do like the bar-height table for a larger group, however the white plastic decor is just a little early-90's-ikea (which was super cool in its day!).  

Anyway, the food was delicious, bottom line. Would highly recommend this place to anyone.
author: Courtney M.

description:
I am from Sacramento and moved into San Francisco last year.  Friends of our Family own many Thai restaurants in Sacramento and they put out some pretty amazing food.  After browsing men at the local bars and a few rounds of Pear 7's a few friends reccomended eating at Thai House.  The food was amazing (BETTER THAN MY DAD'S FRIENDS RESTAURANT) hopefully he doesn't read this review, he will kill me :) haha the Chicken Green Curry is out of this world!!! the Moo Tawt is excellent.  

Thai House needs to work on their NOODLE dishes :)  other than that the food is amazing.
author: Harry K.

description: Pretty good Thai food.  Recommend the Pad Sey Ew and the Vegetable Fried Rice.  Tom Ka Pak is very good.
author: Thomas A.

description:
Food was really good.   Spicy tofu and green beans are a treat.  Tofu crisped up just right and delectable sauce.  

Service was reasonable, though they do tend to do a lot of other things.

Nice atmosphere.  Reasonable prices.  I'll be back.
author: D H.

description:
Really good food. I'm not entirely thrilled by the house music that is sometimes known to be a bit loud sometimes...but it's an exellent restaurant nonetheless.

Their curries are amazing! You'll love it!
author: Peter O.

description:
I read many of the reviews for this place and it seemed that the biggest issue people had was the attitude of the staff as opposed to the food.  I needed to pick up some food to go and so gave this place a try.  I walked in, went to the counter and ordered.  The person who helped me was very nice and explained a couple of things I asked about.  No problem with the staff.  Got a smile and a laugh when I came back to pick up the food 20 minutes later.

The food itself was quite good.  I would have given it 4 stars but for the fact that the veggies in two of the dishes (string bean chicken and prawn red curry) were pretty much the same, string beans, expected in the first dish but thought there'd be something different in the second.   The pad thai was very tasty and the dishes themselves were good, just too many string beans.  Overall, definitely worth a try.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Well, thank you Yelp, once again, for a good suggestion, with accurate ratings.

I have two visitors in town, and after trying to figure out what to have for dinner, we finally settled on Thai, and somewhere not too far.  I was originally thinking the place over on Sanchez and Market, but on a whim checked Yelp one last time to see if there was a better place.  And...here it was.

The food was pretty tasty, the menu standard quick Thai, with a few extras that you won't find anywhere else - to be sure, I ordered something I had never heard of before, and certainly can't remember the name of now.  However, what was kind of scary was the speed at which the food arrived...try less than five minutes.  What?  Either their kitchen is ridiculously fast, or there's a hot table somewhere that I didn't notice.

Perhaps one of the more unique things that I liked about Thai House Express on Castro is their decor.  The place isn't standard cheapie Thai, with either dark woods or some strange sense of green and tropical scenes.  The ambiance is decidedly modern, with stark white walls, dim but "harsh" lighting, and modern art photos on the walls.  In addition, the plating utilizes more modern dishware, lending a sense of updatedness to everything.  But the food remains stoically Thai, and does it well.

Oh, and the prices are certainly comparable to more cheapie Thai places...dinner for three of us and a Thai iced tea for me, tax/tip included, came out to just under $30!

I'll have to head back a few more times and give the menu more of a going over, but considering I ran into another friend while there who is a fan, it probably won't be much of a problem.
author: Mark C.

description: The food here is good, but my friends and I are not going to put up with some of the servers anymore.  Two in particular have offended many of my out of town guests as well as me and my dear San Francisco friends--either with their attitude, comments, or service.   It's too bad because we like the place, but there is other good Thai fare in the hood.
author: OneOfTwo F.

description:
I liked the Chinese place that was a fixture on this corner for decades so it took me a while to check it out when the Thai House moved in...

I found the food to be quite flavorful and delicious but like far too many restaurants in the 'Stro it can get too noisy and crowded at peak times so plan accordingly.
author: Quartknee K.

description:
So my profile says for my last meal I want Green Papaya Salad. I discovered this tastiest of tasty salads in Thailand years ago and I've never forgotten that first plate. I have many a good papaya salad since, but Thai House Express has it nailed. They even have the extra spicy, "I won't survive this meal" version which I usually need to have them tone down a bit.

Pad Thai is the other perennial favorite of Thai lovers that must be done right or all the curry goodness in the world can't make up for it. This place has it! While I have enjoyed Osha Thai for years (long before their chain-like explosion) and our endless supply of others, Thai House Express still takes the bean cake for me. Properly sized noodles - not thin, round, or too flat and wide. Great sauce that doesn't have too much fish sauce or too little either. No piles of cauliflower for us vegetarians - just the same shrimp version without the shrimp.

Another favortie is the Tofu pad ga prow - onions, peppers, fried tofu, stir-fried with basil and a sweetly spiced garlic sauce over rice. This is one of my favorite meals. Get this and a glass of water and you're out the door for $9 after tip. Not a bad at all.

Also, try out the corn cakes to start - really more like a corn fritter - with a little  cucumber/onion/peanut in simply syrup for a topping. My favorite way to start a meal.

The fifth star is reserved for the day time staff. Come in after 6pm on a weekday or late evening on the weekends and you'll have a great time. Before that and the service seems a bit annoyed to be working. Considering how well they do everything, and one or two not-so-enthusiastic wait staff aside - this is one of my favorite Thai hang outs!
author: Ennis O.

description:
Intellectually and culturally I really am done with Thai restaurants opening in the Castro. At last count we had something like six thousand of them in a four block radius. Soon the neighborhood will be known as Little Bangkok. 

BUT this place is good and they have a lot of dishes you don't see at other places. The ambience is hipster (waitresses with ties, lots of stainless steel), so come here when you feel like that's the vibe you want, not when you want comfort food.
author: Tyler S.

description:
Not bad, Castro. Not bad.

This place has decent food, decent atmosphere, and a decent price. It's getting a decent 3 stars from me.

At the very least, it makes Thai Spice in Nob Hill seem like the dried up rabbit turd it is.
author: Brian K.

description:
Thai House Express is my new delicious lunch spot, now that I'm on a diet and eating pizza everyday is against "the rules".

Don't try to tell me that my Tofu Pad Ga-Prow and Thai Iced Tea are just as bad for me, I won't listen to you.

Anyway, this place has a great combo lunch special (appetizer, entree, salad, soup and rice for $8.50), and my half-Thai coworker says that their food is "the best". I just think its delicious, the portions are generous without being embarassing, the food arrives quickly enough that I can have a sit down meal on my 30 minute lunch break.

I withheld that final star because I don't recall ever having a friendly server; they're efficient, and by no means rude, just not friendly. They always just walk me to a table, take the order, bring the food, re-fill the water, drop the check. Maybe they'll say hi, or thank you, but not usually.
author: Vanessa R.

description: Pro tip: If you want it spicy, tell them the waiter you want it so hot that "I leave here in an ambulance."
author: Dave N.

description:
Servers are attitude princesses that can't be bothered to come to the table, or wipe it down once they do deign to serve. 

We specified "hot and spicy, " and what arrived was the blandest, greasiest Thai meal we've ever had in ten years in SF.

You want decent Thai food with waiters who at least pretend to care about what they're doing?  Thai Cafe around the block.  But for now, someone is DEFINITELY not paying attention at this place.
author: Dennis T.

description: Selection of food here is great, it reminds me of lovely simple meal we, thai people, usually eat in Thailand. Duck laab is delicious, Tom yum noodle soup tastes too artificial lime juice to me. I want to give this place more star but after many disappointment episodes from the staff here, I banned this place from now.  What wrong with their attitude, if they don't want to work then don't! They always make me feel like I'm begging them for everything, same experience for both dine-in and take-out.
author: Kong S.

description: Awesome Thai restaurant with very fair prices!  Beware, when they say spicy they mean SPICY... when they don't say spicy... its still probably pretty spicy...  I totally love this place- very neat setting, not too loud that you can't hear your date, great food, reasonable prices, orgasmic thai tea- let me rephrase that- ORDER THE ICED THAI TEA!!
author: Bobby P.

description:
I started eating at the T.H.E. in the 'Loin.  Hands down the best pad thai I've ever had.  And the bathroom upstairs was blasting good-ass tunes.  
When it moved to the Castro I knew I was in heaven.  The food's great and I love how the waitstaff wear wife-beaters and ties....get it?! Ties at Thai!  hahahahahaha.......i love this place.
author: Mz M.

description:
The Thai House Express has derailed.

I used to love this place. But something terrible must have happened. We ordered take-out, and everything was way below expectations. Chicken coconut soup was very watery and the chicken dry.  The five-spice duck was bland and the only thing that saved it from being as dry as the soup chicken was a tremendous layer of fat.  Don't get me wrong, I love duck fat - but that was too much even for my taste. The stuffing of their signature appetizer - chicken & veggie pouch - also dry (I was looking for some dipping sauce, in vain).  One could think that their kitchen struck by famine... But no, there was plenty of gravy in Rad Na - so much, as a matter of fact, that noodles were difficult to fish out.  Those that we WERE able to find, were overcooked and mushy...  Kinda sad.  

The staff's attitude has become pretty special too.  I recommend adding tiaras to their dress code - just to avoid confusion.
author: Z P.

description:
I'm not a fan of rude waiters.

We ordered the cripsy pork with thai iced tea. The iced tea didn't come and I had to remind the 'waiter with an attitude'  that we ordered it. He glared at me and rolled his eyes. You're kidding right? Ok, hey, if you don't want a tip, go ahead and act like an ass. 

We ordered the crispy pork and were charged $8.25 for a small plate of crispy pork and another $1.25 for rice. When I asked why the rice wasn't included I couldn't get an answer. The 'waiter with an attitude' wouldn't wait on us and made a waitress finish out his service. She didn't know what we ordered even though it was written on our check. (I couldn't read it)

The cripsy pork was 30% pork, 20% crispy and 50% grease. I could have lubed my car with what was left on my plate. 

This passes for food and service? 
Never again.
author: Ty M.

description:
Come here for the ambience, not really for the food. Well, I take that back, the food isn't too bad. The soup you get with the lunch special was weird though- pseudo chicken veg type soup? I can't quite pinpoint what it was. I thought you should get that typical spicy/sweet soup? Oh well. 
Well, I ordered the lunch special. The spicy was a little to spicy for me. The thai ice tea was typical- a little too sweet for my palate though. Overall, its just alright. I would go to King of Thai instead.
author: T H.

description: this is pretty much the only thai place i go to in castro b/c its the ONLY one ( i swear to god) that has sticky rice. i feel like i go to so many other thai places, even in other neighborhoods, and they don't have sticky rice! wtf! its like a tailor not selling suits. also, EVERYONE that works here is FUKIN GAY, so i support that. fully. werk.
author: Teal S.

description: It's turned into my go-to Thai in the city. Pad see ew, duck curry, and eggplant is now my regular order.
author: Eric M.

description: This is a little place that is trying to be trendy Thai. It's been a while since I went, but I think it was overpriced for lunch and the food was OK. Nothing memorable about it. The environment was cute, but not compelling. The owners should try Osha.
author: Andrew K.

description: Pleasant food, decor and service. The food is awesome. We went with the fried tofu and samosas-like appetizers. Tasty! I ordered from the vegetarian menu- a mushroom, carrot, celery, and tofu gravy dish w/ rice. Huge portions, and not too salty or savory. Tasty! Servers who be lookin good. Tasty! Affordable prices for dinner- about $15/person. Tasty!
author: Thomas L.

description: I realllly love this place..I've only been a couple times, but have been blown away each time!  All the food ive had has been delicious, with the exception of the pork being a little too fatty, but that could have just been a bad cut..my favorite thing about this restaurant, is that i can eat everything on the menu because everything is made with coconut milk, and not regular milk which because of my lactose intolerance, i have cut out of my diet...the only other negative thing i can say about this place, is that their servers are not the nicest, and when taking your order have that "are you almost done?" attitude as they are staring out the window and seeming that they arent paying attention to you..overal..ill be back considering its in the heart of my favorite part of the city :)
author: Gary H.

description:
loooove the older woman that serves here. she's engaging and brings the food out quick. they play great music during your meal service. best thai iced tea in the castro. the food rivals any of the other places nearby. 
very good and i highly reccommend.
author: Anthony I.

description:
OK, I must be getting REAL old, but this really bothered me. We went here for dinner tonight, as we have many times before. One of the waiters was wearing a shirt with an image of a donkey and an elephant with the caption: "everyone poops." the shirt  showed one of them pooping and another pile of poop under the other one. Now, I am all for freedom of expression, but come on. Having to be served by a waiter who has images of two piles of shit on his shirt?!??! This was a first for me. I think it was utterly inappropriate and off-putting.

That said, we always have enjoyed the food here. Service can be unpredictable though: sometimes very friendly and efficient, other times stand offish or perfunctory at best.

OK, enough venting for one night!

Update: in general the service has been better over the last few months. and the food remains consistently pleasing. the corn fritters are to die for!

November '09 Update: although we still like going here occasionally for some of the better Thai food in town, especially the curries, for the most part the service has become very noticeably indifferent and even dismissive at times.
author: Eric P.

description:
Just went there tonight...it was awful.  Huge disappointment. I have been to the other location at Larkin and Geary and that one's great.    The Castro location had very slow, poor and rudeservice.    But worse of all, the food was incredibly bad.  
      Don't order the chicken wing appetizer .  EAch  wing or drummette was half the size of what you would expect from a regular chicken and tasted old.   The chicken  in the yellow curry was the same...the meat was not fresh.......the sauce was good but didn't make up for the old tasting meat.
The beef balls in my beef noodle soup were hard and did not taste fresh either. 
      
The person who greeted us at the door  tried to lead us to the table next to  the door.  We asked to sit toward the back because it was cold, and he refused saying the back was closed...but there were other people there.      I noticed that one of the reviews for this restaurant stated that the staff treated asians  poor compared to other patrons....  I don't like to bring race into this .but I'm asian and they wouldn't seat me where I asked...yet the worker seated a group of all white patrons in the back that came in after me.   
       There are plenty of  Thai restaurants that are good in the city....avoid this one!!!!    I really wanted to like this restaurant since it's in my neighborhood.
author: Nile L.

description: I wish I could say I'm a fan but the service is horrible here every time I go. I love their food, just desire less attitude with the dish.
author: Joe W.

description:
3 stars for flavor, 5 stars for value = 4 star average.
Admittedly, we only got take out, but the size of the green curry tub (the a la carte option) must have been a full quart!  Really quite absurd for only $9.  $20 total got 2 people at least 2 LARGE meals.
My flavor issue?  Mostly with the green curry - it was fine, but didn't have the depth or richness of flavor that I've come to appreciate in truly amazing green curry.  Nice amount of spice though.
author: Don H.

description:
BATHROOM REVIEW
--------------------------------
I need to start the review with my typical bathroom banter since I didn't realize how cool it was until tonight. The men's bathroom has some wavy mirror right next to the toilet which adds a new dimension to "taking a leak." There is just something amusing about watching a stream of tinkle in a wavy mirror. Not to mention, it would probably be even more amusing under the influence. Call me perverted and disgusting, but I bet you'll take my advice next time you are in Thai House Express and walk out of the bathroom pleasantly surprised.

FOOD
----------

Now onto the food ...

Thai House Express was our de facto Thai restaurant when we lived on Upper Market. We just didn't like the others in the area after eating around. After moving to the Mission, we still go back. The food is cheap. The food is good. And their menu is enormous! Really, it doesn't get much better than that. 

Now, if you go to Thai House, you HAVE TO GET the Okie Ducky. Hands down, it is the best dish I have ever had at Thai House. So good that I get it every single time. And here's a little tip. Take the leftovers and throw it into a bowl of Mac n' Cheese the next day for a culinary orgasm. Truly, it is the most baller Mac n' Cheese you'll ever eat. That is, unless you are me since I prefer shaved truffles on mine.

All in all, I have only been let down once when I went here and asked the waiter for his recommendation between the two dishes. I took his advice and I didn't really like my dish. Other than that, I haven't had a bad dish yet. The portions are huge and the price is right. You can't really beat that combination. 

Best Dish List
-------------------
1. Okie Ducky
2. Moo Tod (# 81)
3. Pad Kee Mao
author: Bathrooms Only ..

description:
For a place with "Express" in its name, we weren't expecting much.

First thought: I want to bathe and become one with their peanut sauce. I wanted to lick the bowl of our Toong Gern Yueng, but I didn't. That's not proper. The cucumber salad rocked. I normally ignore cucumber salads, but this one captured my attention. 

Second thought: I felt like the other guy, where I had to give the "puppy dog eyes" in order to be able to order. But our waiter was super nice. We liked him. 

Third thought: We had our normally mentioned toddler with us and they totally didn't mind that she didn't order and sat there chomping on pickles, pizza and crackers that make her oh-so-happy. 

We're a fan. Good food. Shared plates and spent $19. Happy :o)h
author: Kristin H.

description:
Absolutely solid Thai food, pleasant and pretty -- that goes for both the space and the staff -- and a few bucks cheaper than others. There is absolutely no reason not to go here on a regular basis if you're in the neighborhood. Thai standards are delicious, but definitely sample widely. I branched out and had some roasted pork in special gravy sauce that was so delicious, I asked the dude next to me how I could've been sleepin on the roasted pork all this time? He said I should branch out and try some other things too, and if I liked he could let me sample some off-menu items in the back room where they make the special sauce. Gosh, some people are just friendly for no reason at all.

Extra star for adding an extremely good AND extremely good value option to the Castro!

UPDATE 2/26/06: Went late last night and they were sooo off. Minus 1 star, hope it was a fluke.
author: Tom L.

description:
SF has few Thai restaurants that i think are exceptional.  This is a good Thai restaurant but i do not think it is exceptional.  There is no particular dish that I think stands out from other Thai restaurants.  The food is fresh and high on the wow-my-taste-buds are enjoying this ride.  But I think many / most Thai restaurants fail in trying to have the standard fare dishes but have a few exciting original dishes that hark back to unique Thai flavourings.

Buen Provecho!
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
I went to thai house for a late lunch the other day...  i hadn't had thai in a bit (well not long for other people but long for me) so i was excited.  I had a tofu red curry dish that was so good!  The rice that came with it was delicious, i wish i had had enough apetite to eat it all.  My friend had chicken green curry, which was also very tasty, and my other friend had duck, which he liked although i didn't try it (don't like duck).  Our thai iced tea was good too.  There was a mango sticky rice dessert advertised all over which i really wanted to try (it sounded so good my friend was obsessing over it the day after) but will have to wait till i have more room in my tummy!
the decor was more restauranty looking than more authentic thai places, but it wasnt really more expensive.  i would go there again, although i still want to try more different ones first.

PS - I did go there again!  I had to wait so long for my tofu green curry that my friends were done before I got mine! Bad service! The pineapple fried rice dish my friend ate had no meat or veggies in it as advertised, but the shrimp tomato pineapple dish my other friend had was good.  As was the hidden shrimp appetizer...
author: Merredith L.

description:
I found the indifference of the wait staff amusing, it was in a way, very like Kao San Road, Bangkok. Believe you me, certainly not a standard for Thai food by any measure, but for service? Bemused ignoring peppered with a 'busy' after taste.

The food however stands up. I ordered a Green Papaya Salad bc I have to. It is the way I know, is it Thai? Happily, although the papaya was not macerated with the lime marinade, but rather bathed in it, it had a good range of spice and fish. 

My tofu green curry at ~$8.50'ish was average, but they did have the wide rice noodles which are a personal favorite. Hey, Thai House, if you dip noodles into boiling water for just a sec or two, they will separate AND heat up. Just you know, a hint I saw on the streets of Thailand. 

My dining companion ordered rice and veggies and it was a nice assortment of veggies although the brown 'sauce' was dangerously close to the ubiquitous 'brown sauce de Chinese'. So, I can't rave.

The Thai Iced Teas were creamy but not tangy, sort of weak tea, but I enjoyed it all the same. 

I would go back, it was reasonably priced and tasty enough. I can see if I lived nearby how it might become a standard, but that would be bc of proximity and not for outrageous, authentic flavor.
author: Miel H.

description:
5 for decor, 4 for food, 3 for service. Average: 4 out of 5 stars.
Definitely a safe bet but not the holy grail of Thai.
author: Jamie F.

description:
The food here was superb. My favorite Thai dish is pad see-ew and the noodles were perfectly cooked with the great sauce evenly distributed. The Chinese broccoli and the beef are really tasty too. We also had the tom-gae soup, the broth was coconut based and the it was really unique and yummy. 

The atmosphere is nice, the big dining room has high ceilings and there's a sophisticated/casual feel. They also played some good techno beats. 

I was really disappointed with the service. They forgot our drink orders and our food came so we didn't really care, but on our billed, they charged us for the drinks. And they were super slow on service, they had 3-4 servers running around on all the tables and also take phone/delivery orders. Needless to say, it took forever getting our billed fixed and getting our change. I felt like the even though the food was good, the service sucked so much that I rather find another place.
author: Gladys C.

description:
Time/Date: Tuesday  7:50 pm. We did a walkin but were seated right away.

Type/Quality: Thai food. Its good.

Price/Quanity: Under 20 bucks a person gets you each an entree dish and a split appetizer. You can easily have leftovers.

Service/Accesibility: The service is friendly and attentive. Parking is tough since its on one of the first blocks in the castro.

Structure/Ambience: The structure was an upstairs of an SF victorian thats been redone and turned into a quaint restaurant with a view of the castro. Its got relaxed lighting and a nice quiet atmosphere great for casual conversation. Its vaugly reminisent of the red light district in amsterdam.
author: Justin L.

description: I side with the other poor reviews.  The staff seems to not care and the food is average.  Last time I got beef with straw mushrooms in oyster sauce the beef was like rubber.  This place has good hours and is super convenient location-wise for me.  I just wish it were better.
author: Sin F.

description:
Meh.  It's pretty inside and the staff is nice.

The pad thai is just okay.  The panang beef, which is a peanuty and salty sweet combo at most SF Thai restaurants, is only salty - but salty to the point of being almost inedible.  

This should sum it all up: I'm on a mission to find the best Thai places in SF.  I go back to the places I like.  I'm definitely not going back because the other places I've been to are so much tastier.
author: A A.

description:
My favorite thai restaurant in the area and been there many times. I like the wide selection of food. I also like the rather modern design of the interior and the good energy. Not good for a romantic night, though...

Good staff, too.
author: bart m.

description: Delicious authentic Thai, great service, decent pricepoint
author: Eric O.

description:
One star for the UNSANITARY and UNHEALTHY kitchen practices.

I have eaten here a number of times since they opened and find the food okay, nothing to rave about but nothing to pan either.  Like their name says, they're express and the food gets out to the table fast.  However, I will never eat here again: the last time I ate here, I sat at a table that looked right into the kitchen.  A woman in there was preparing a dish to go out, dropped a spoon on the floor and stuck it right in the dish and sent it out.  I raised a loud stink with the staff and who I think was the manger, and told them they need to throw out that dish out and serve those patrons a fresh one.  Sorry, the "five second rule" does not work for me.
author: Adam Z.

description:
Prompt, friendly service + fresh-tasting Thai + the Castro + family and friends = one fabulous summer evening. 

A family friend who lives in the neighborhood took us here last night, along with my aunt and my cousin. They promptly accomodated the five of us sans reservation and brought us water right away (big points from me on this small detail). 

The atmosphere is very basic but pleasant, just don't go here for ambiance.  Our server was very efficient and nice. Beer was served with frosty mugs and the water kept coming -- key when contending with spicy food!  

The vegetarian menu section was much appreciated as were the notes about vegetarian items elsewhere on the menu, like apps and soups.  We shared the chive cakes, which were unique and quite tasty if a little bit mushy -- and the serving was very generous.  We also shared the fresh and perky cucumber salad with onion, with that unique slightly sweet Thai dressing. My gang pak -- red curry with tofu and vegetables -- was very delicious and I scarfed down the whole thing. It was also just mildly spicy, which I had requested from the helpful server.  I ordered the smaller "over rice" portion with brown rice, which was also generously served.  

Everyone else seemed happy with their choices, as well -- definitely recommend it for Thai lovers and the Thai-curious (sorry, I couldn't resist...!).
author: Karen W.

description:
One of my regular Thai hangouts.

I miss the Thai House on noe.
The service is more abrupt and hurried, but the food remains good and tasty. The modern setting allows for a mized casual setting or great when on a date before a show.

My favorite is the Thai House Beef.
The BBQ Beef and the Green Chili Sauce is simple but tasty and addictive.
author: Joe R.

description:
This is good, clean Thai food with a lot of variety on the menu. Staff is nice, though not as nice as Thai people are famous for being for some reason, i.e., no sawadeekas here.

Always happy to eat here anytime as the food is consistently good and quick. You can't beat the lunch special either which for $9 and some odd cents including tax gets you an appetizer, soup, salad, rice and an entree.

Friday nights are fun, casual and lively with a hip urban crowd and light house/circuity music playing away. The rest of the week it's just a good local joint that will definitely take care of any cravings you are having for some good Thai food.
author: James H.

description:
I'm so addicted to this place!  Seriously, when I want Thai food this is one of two place I go to and have no desire to try anywhere else.  The green curry chicken, panang beef curry, those deep fried pouches of minced chicken...sooo good!

The only thing which stopped the 5 star rating was their customer service.  When they get busy the service can be painful (rude, slow and lacking).

As with all restaurants, I typically check the health department's website to see the food score on the restaurant.  You might want to check this one...they had some issues in the past.
author: Mike C.

description: The food is always great.  Chicken with Basil and the Crab Pad Thai.  YUMMY
author: priscilla p.

description:
I used to order from here fairly often. I like authentic Thai food a lot, and, occasionally, you'd get a good cook (or the cook was having a good day) and the food would be fantastic. Most of the time, it was okay. Unfortunately, the quality of the food has declined significantly. I've been eating there less and less frequently. However, last night was the first time I have ever actually returned take out food. Each of the five dishes we ordered was way below acceptable and two of the dishes were just flat-out disgusting; they had even forgotten several of the ingredients in some of the dishes. After a couple of bites, I was scared to eat any of it other than the sticky rice. 

When I called to complain, they explained that they were very busy that evening (I suppose the five Tuesday night diners must have all ordered at once), and that that could explain why the food was so poor. I guess that means that if they are busy, you take your chances... 

I, however, will not be taking any chances here again.

Follow up - I've been asked for examples. One example: The Som Tam (green papaya salad) did not have any chilis, dried shrimp or garlic in it, and if it had lime, I certainly couldn't taste it - these are all essential, and approximately half of the, ingredients to som tam. What it did have, and in large quantities, was undisolved sugar and fish sauce - without those ingredients and with the overabundance of sugar, it all just tasted like a sickeningly-sweet, syrupy, slightly rancid (from the fish sauce) apple salad with fine sand in it.
author: Peter S.

description:
I really like this place! It is great that they actually have caddies of chili flakes, sauce and stuff on the table, and if you want things spicy, which I do, ask for it extra spicy!  
Consistently really good food and so close to my house make this a winner for me! Two of my favorites: panang beef curry and pad thai.
Service is usually pretty prompt, and friendly!
author: Scott H.

description:
You gotta love a Thai restaurant where the hostess is named Tup Tim (like one of the wives in the King and I movie musical)!  I don't actually know if she still works there, but I know that was her name because she had a long chat with a friend of mine visiting from Thailand.  He confirmed that the food isn't authentic, but he really enjoyed the meal nonetheless.  It was the only place I took him to that he asked to go back to.  Now if that isn't a good recommendation for a Thai place, then I don't know what is!

I've always enjoyed this place since it first opened (when the servers wore matching striped polos from American Eagle).  The food has been consistently outstanding, and they can make it as spicy as you want.  Not the lame American taste bud brand of spicy, but the rest of the world brand that makes the flavors dance in your mouth.  I particularly enjoy the fresh spring rolls, larb gai, beef panang curry, pad thai, and the fried whole fish with sweet sauce on their specials menu.  The place can get busy during dinner, but they take to go orders.  Yes!  The service can also be slow at times, but just be aggressive when flagging down your server.  

Note:  My bf recently told me that the food was shockingly bad during his visit last week.  Bad enough for him to wonder if they've gotten new chefs or are under new management.  I hope this was just a fluke because there are not enough good Thai restaurants nearby.
author: Vicente G.

description:
Its a cute space at the end of the main Castro drag, no pun intended.
The service has always been good, and a majority of the time the food has been great, with a few ocassions where I left disappointed. But I attributed it to being an off night. 

I don't think the food is particularly authentic, but most Thai places cater to the American tastebud anyways, so no biggie. Considering that there aren't many Thai places in the 'stro, I think this one will get you to that fuzzy zone of deliciousness.
author: Venatius P.

description:
Why is it I'm not a big fan of most restaurants in Castro?

The food here is good, I will give them that.  It's not great, but it's good.  Most of the staff was friendly, but one of them bugged the hell out of me.  I mean, why would you walk up to the table and move my silverware closer to me and fill up my water?  No...  Why would you take the bill from the table before I've left?  No...  He just irked me.

The restaurant itself is sterile.  Tall white walls, white chairs, silver accents, silver tables (or were they white?).  Regardless, the only warm tones the place had was the kitchen/bar area.  I did notice the bathrooms were quite clean, which is always a nice thing.

I feel like I had better Thai food at Neecha Thai Cuisine in Pacific Heights and over in Berkeley at Tuk Tuk Thai Cafe.  If I were in a pinch and wanted some food, I would probably pick this place over many others, but it wouldn't necessarily be my first choice.  I think Lime and Barracuda would be the first options, with this place being a backup.
author: Brent A.

description: Nothing particularly interesting to say about Thai House Express.  It's Thai in the Castro with a hint of decor.  It offers consistently good food, non-offensive service, and reasonable prices.  Probably better than the Thai places around it, but sometime you have to wait.
author: Luke M.

description: Best Pad Thai I've ever had! Fast friendly service. Can't wait till I get another chance to come back.
author: Patrick L.

description:
The food is always very good, and I especially like the #42 (don't ask me to spell or pronounce it - it's yummy and noodley and yellow curry-y).  

My only complaint:  Please turn down the radio!  92.7 blaring in your ears while eating can get a bit annoying.
author: Marcus C.

description:
Fast, convenient and great.  You can't beat the location and service.
There is fancier Thai food in town, but convenience and consistency compel me to give Thai House 4 stars.
author: Bradford S.

description:
Predicably good. That says a lot of restaurants in the Castro. I live just one block away. Love calling in for take out. Avoid the chicken, too dry.
They don't quite have the finesse of a chinese restaurant, but hey, it's close to my house, and I know what to order there.
author: Pandora B.

description:
I love this place, and am a regular here after yoga class. Be sure to order the Kao Ka Moo (the inadequately described "special pork leg stew") over rice, which I never would have ordered if the guy next to me hadn't been eating it. It's incredibly tender and flavorful pork that must be cooked with star anise, with tasty pickled greens on the side. I don't recommend the sauce that comes with it, because it overpowers the pork's subtle flavor. 

Other solid choices are the Tom Yum Goong, Crispy Catfish, Pad Thai, Pad Se-Ew, and Kao Soy (I like it best with the wide rice noodles), but I've never had a dish here I didn't like. Arrive hungry!
author: Sharman G.

description:
A solid, neighborhood Thai place! 

Recently, I had the salmon wrapped in banana leaves, chicken green curry, pad thai, and pork with cabbage.  All of it was very good, except for the pork dish.  

Dishes are served as either individual "rice plates" or "a la carte" to share.

Enjoy :)
author: Carol L.

description: Best damn Thai food in the city, hands down!
author: Ben M.

description: I've been to this restaurant about 8 times over the past 3 years and every time it has been a great experience. The servers have always approached the table at the right times and the food always arrives quickly, without seeming like fast food. Everything I've had is delicious and cooked perfectly with great presentation. I like the ambiance: tall ceilings bright walls, big windows, modern tables and chairs with simple black & white floral paintings on the walls. For a casual restaurant I have to say it's my favorite in SF.
author: Justin B.

description: I was soooooo hungry and I had been rushing around all day.  I figured no better time then the present to try some thai in san fran.  Stopped here to put in an order of food to-go and was so hungry didnt even want to look at the menu i just ordered the simple and easy cashew nut chicken.  My food was made really quicklym within 5 minutes and when I got home to eat it, ohhhhhh yeah.   It was really really good.  It wasnt salty (which happens alot with thai places) and the chicken was all white meat.  I loved it, I would def go back there to try more dishes.  Its a nice spot, its not authentic its more american type thai food but good and the restaurant is really nice, lots of windows, pretty modern, and clean. thumbs up.
author: Alexis R.

description:
This place rocks!!!  I love the food there... urr... is it that I was so drunk I couldn't tell the diff...   anyhoo....  This place has amazing food and the turnover is pretty fast so you can always get a seat in a few minutes.

They should open another one in the Ferry Building and charge 25 bucks a plate.
author: Sang L.

description:
Yum yum yum. Especially if you're veggie. The ambiance is great, nice and upbeat. 

Not recommended for parties of more than 4 or 5.

Not recommended if you're too drunk to appreciate what you're eating. I've been there and it just won't satisfy.
author: C S.

description:
This place has cratered.  Unfortunate, but the reality of the scenario.
I live around the corner from this restaurant and considered it a reasonable place.  But, three "meals" in a row, dished up as crap motivates me to issue this warning.  Find another restaurant.
Cold meals, soup with nothing in it, having to wave at the waiter to remind him to deliver a beer; and it was a warm beer when it finally arrived.  Next!
This place has imploded.  Plus, the waiters dish up an "Attitude" when one asks / reminds them of the other components to your order.
Done.  Was once a favorite, but no longer.  You would have to pay me cash to show up at this place.
author: John B.

description:
Location is nice - and the place looks cool and cosy from the outside, and is quite nice inside.

Food is OK - especially the meet. But it lacks flavor, it lacks spices, it lacks what makes thai food so unique. So it's OK if you are in the neighborhood, but if you want serious thai, there are way better places not far away from this spot (like Thep Phanom or Regent Thai in Noe Valley)
author: Pascal L.

description: I love the extensive menu, reasonable prices, generous portions and delicious food at Thai House Express.  The decor is nothing to write home about, but maybe that's what contributes to the affordability of the menu.  Surrounded by a million overpriced eats in the Castro, this place is just right for a quick, tasty bite.
author: Dave N.

description:
I have been here several times because I live in the neighborhood.  The first time I went I had an eggplant and beef dish with brown rice that I loved.  I couldn't stop talking about how great it was.  So then I went back and have tried several other things.  Unfortunately, I don't think I have been impressed since.  I had chicken in a peanut sauce last time, and the chicken was literally dripping in gooey peanut butter sauce.  A little might have been good, but I had to scoop most of the sauce off onto a side plate, and still it was too much.  The staff also varies from mildly nice to mildly annoyed for no reason.

I'll end on a nice note though.  Its very modern with cool tables and chairs and a nice layout.  I guess its not a bad joint to get a cheap meal on Tuesday if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Tony B.

description: I stumbled across this place and wondered if it is the same as the one  I love on Larkin street.  Looked it up on yelp and saw the 3.5 stars...pacing outside debating if I should go.  I am so glad i decided to go in!  Still unsure if they are related or just have the same name, I was very pleased with their food.  The decor is really nice and the place is clean.  We ordered the most typical dishes - pad thai and tom yum soup.  I think you can pretty much judge how good they are if they can master the basic dishes.  Like I said, I thought their food was amazing.  The meat in the soup was good quality and the portion was very generous.  I would definitely come back and try others dishes.
author: e c.

description:
TOM KHA GAI( hot and sour chicken soup with coconut) is amazing! Egg Rolls are pretty good. 
Try their Lunch Specials...it comes with a salad, a soup and some appetizers. Very good deal!
author: Lavinia W.

description: Had dinner here last weekend and enjoyed it.  It was good food and good service at a decent price...not great, but very good.  The food was ready very fast.  I would recommend Thai Place for a nice casual dinner.
author: Tony H.

description: Its the only place my husband and I can agree on to eat. Everything we have gotten their is amazing and clean food... not alot of fat no chemicals all super fresh... Their Vegetarian dishes are absolutely amazing. But for you meat eaters my husband is always happy by his selections and they look tasty. Really good Pad Thai. Go for it you won't be disappointed.
author: amy g.

description:
This use to be my go-to Thai restaurant when in the Castro.  Now, I have second thoughts...

Buyer beware:
http://sf.everyblock.com/restaurant-inspections/by-date/2010/12/17/4565327/
author: rodney g.

description: Been going here for years as a near by spot.  It definitely goes up and down.  Loved it at first 5 years ago, then it got crappy and the service sucked on multiple occasions, but lately it is decent flavors and improved service.  I can just never tell what I will get when I return, but as of last week, it was good. There are better Thai places, but for convenience sake it is pretty darn good.
author: Joseph F.

description:
The best Thai in the Castro or Noe that I've found.  Not as good as Lingba but I can walk home with take-out.

Yummy soups, fun-intimate dining, industrial-chic setting (my first impression  was it was a little rough/dive-y but my second visit showed I must not have looked around that carefully).

I'll be back and I'll be back with friends.
author: Lm C.

description:
Maybe I haven't been to enough Thai restaurants in the city....

but I loved their Pad Thai best of all the noodles I've had in San Francisco.

And the ground chicken in a pouch thing was really good too! That doesn't sound at all appetizing I know!  But it really was! (If only I could remember the name....)

It took a while to get the food and the bill.....so you can't be in too much of a rush here. But the server was cute and so was my company....so it didn't matter to me.
author: Vikki P.

description: I was visiting San Francisco last week and had dinner here with some friends.  I remember the food being good and I appreciated them being able to seat a table of seven guys at 8:30 PM.
author: Matt B.

description: From the outside Thai House Express does not look like much. It's interiors are pretty plain as well, with white walls and not much decoration. This retaurant is pretty nice though- spacious and very clean. Their menu is basic, the service is good... and as for the food? The food is awesome! Thai House Express is definitely one of the better Thai places I have been to in the city. My friend and I shared three dishes: Tom Kah with tofu, Pad Thai and green papaya salad. This was more than enough food for both us and came out to a little over twenty dollars- what a deal!! The soup was amazing, the Pad Thai was good and the papaya salad was pretty good, as well, even though the portion was really small. I will definitely eat here again!
author: Daniela A.

description: Thai House Express on Castro used to be tasty, or maybe that was just the grand opening buzz of it. I'm convinced it is not what it used to be. Could it be there was a change in chef? They admit to adding MSG to their food, which in my opinion is not the Thai way of cooking. Plus, when I went there to have a nice bowl of noodle soup, I got a way scaled down version of what it used to be, all cramped into a small square bowl. There were a lot of bean sprouts and a measly pinch of noodles that didn't fill me up. It sure did have a lot of flavor though, but I suspect it was thanks to MSG. Unfortunate that things have changed and I try not to support restaurants that use  MSG in their cooking so I likely will not be back. It's harmful to some, like me, and there is no need for it if the cook knows how to season properly. As for service, my waiter was nicer than the usual bunch that is there and a lot more attentive. That was a positive change!
author: Foodie F.

description: Who knew you could get reasonable delicious thai food outside of the sunset. I didn't think the city allowed the Thai people to leave their enclave but I was happily proven wrong after wine tasting at Swirl. Thai food is thai food and it runs the gamete from good to bad like all others but here at Thai House express they are winning the race.
