I enjoyed that the people at the table next to me weren't afraid to lean over and beg of me what I was eating and I was more then obliged to share that the Pad Kee Mao with shrimp was fab! Also you should check out their website: http://www.thhexpress.com/ it is just cool and way more then one would expect from a thai places website.
author: Brian S.

description: Good Thai food. Vegetarian-friendly menu. I tried the vegetarian Pad Kee Mao (#66) and Tofu Pad Khing (#98) - both were well-made, with plenty of veggies and tofu. Good portion sizes for the price (under $8). I was a little surprised at how quickly the food was prepared...but, the food was all well-cooked (the ginger and carrots didn't seem under-cooked, the chinese broccoli was crunchy, and the fried tofu wasn't chewy). Friendly service. I'd go here again.
author: Shweta V.

description: Always hot, fresh and tasty. The coconut soup with tofu has more veggies than the one with chicken, but I love them both. I like all the curries, but the red always rocks. Un-bland Pad Thai! YES! (And they can make it really spicy if you want.) Great spring rolls, and for a noodle dish I love the Pad Kee Mow the best. The In-Laws always require Choo-Chee Salmon when they visit. We love this place and drive over the hill to get it from Glen Park, since our local Osha Thai is - I'm sorry to say - just terrible.
author: Mark A.

description: Pad Thai Kicks Ass. End of story.
author: Bluey B.

description: I just came back home from lunch at Thai House. The service was terrible and the chicken yellow curry awful. It was my first time, you received what you pay in reataurants. Its a cheap place so the food quality is poor. I will never go back again to Thai house. Terrible service and food. My friends got sick after we ate there.
author: Rido Q.

description: This place is super yummy and cheap. The portions are big and the menu is long, so go here if you're looking for good Thai food in the Castro.
author: Jennifer H.

description: 3.5 - This is a fantastic lunch place.  It is a late review (went a month ago) so neither one of us exactly remember what we had but it was good.  We have gone by this place a few times for dinner but the lights are just too bright inside and ruin a dinner atmosphere - so lunch it is and you will not be disappointed.  Service was ok.
author: Jessica M.

description:
i really like the nuer kem which is their beef jerky for an appetizer. never had or even heard of it before.

one of my regular orders is prig king or sometimes spelled prig khing, or pad pric khing and is made with chicken with string beans. that is my go to dish and judge of a thai place. they make it good here however it is spelled. i see here it is also made with pork. i have had other pork dishes and they were good. 

i haven't had a bad dish here except they lag on hotness when i ask for it hot and spicy. maybe thai places have trouble with folks who order it hot then want to send it back because it is too hot for them. too bad if you ask me.

it is usually crowed so that tells me they do a good business with good turnover of food. unlike rasha near our place that is sure to close down if they don't get some business.

i wish this place was closer to our home so i could walk there for takeout. we never feel like unparking the car and driving anywhere so when we crave thai we go right near our home. but i like this place so i should drive over every now and then.
author: roger b.

description: Jumped in here for some dinner after a haircut the other night. After much discussion on where to go and what to eat we decided to get some thai since it was close. So i guess we lucked out getting to go here. The menu is a little daunting at first if you don't know what you are in the mood for. Tons of rice, noodle and soup dishes and a decent vegiterian selection. Do yourself a favor and get some veg chive cakes #11. they will knock your socks off. Really good. I got some fried rice which was very good as well. Service was good as well.
author: Stephen K.

description: This place is awesome. Where else can you sit on comfortable seats, listen to 92.7, and eat good Thai food. Well probably another place on Castro street but I haven't found those other places yet.
author: Tim M.

description: Tasty Thai that's definitely express. Was perfect except the not-so-express desert we ordered.
author: Scott M.

description: Pretty decent thai food.  The Phad Thai is raved to be the best in the bay area.  I'm not sure about that but it was not *my* favorite Phad Thai.  The portion was a decent size and overall the flavor was good but I wish it had some fresh lime.  Maybe that isn't authentic but I love some fresh lime with Phad Thai.  Even though it was not my all time favorite, I would definitely go back and have it again.  We also tried the Toong Gern Yeung dumplings.   The flavors were nice and I really liked the sweet cucumber sauce that came with it but the texture was not quite what I expected.  The filling was super crumbly and a tad dry.  Still tasty and satisfying though.
author: Laura B.

description: I wasn't crazy about my BBQ chicken (admittedly probably not the best thing to order when there was so much other good stuff on the menu) but the shrimp starter was good and my friend's pad thai was super good. Prices were very ok too.
author: Carrie A.

description: Always awesome Thai food and always awesome service. Bank and the rest are awesome at their job and honestly can't ever be paid enough for how hard they work. I've brought so many people to this place and even though I no longer live in San Francisco, I still make this my regular stop when I visit back there.
author: Chadwick H.

description: For the price, location and quality this is a great place.  The waiters are nice and you get your food quickly.  When I'm there I usually have pineapple fried rice or pad thai with veggies but lately I've been trying some of the spicy stuff.  You get plenty of food at very reasonable prices, what more do you want?
author: Eric v.

description: A coworker told me that his wife who moved from Thailand to the U.S. about 4 years ago said this it the best Thai Restaurant in San Francisco. That was enough to convince me. I tried, and I liked it. It was good. I would eat there again if I was in the Castro and hungry for Asian food, but nothing really stood out. Nothing to make me drag a friend over there to see how good it is.
author: Johnny O.

description: Insanely-great Thai. Best Thai I've had anywhere in the Bay Area and the prices are good too. The Red Curry Beef is a favourite of mine, the Green Curry is upwardly mobile and Pad Thai lovers will not be disappointed! Face the facts people - you need to eat there.
author: Chris K.

description:
3.5 stars.

the decor in this place is cute and modern. i had the tom yum noodle soup with what i thought i ordered was egg noodles, but the noodles looked different to me. you get a choice between flat rice noodles, egg noodles, and a sticky rice noddle, which i dunno what that is, but the lady said they were thin. nonetheless, still tasted good. i love thai flavors and spice, and this soup hit the spot! i also had spring rolls to start off with, but i think they called them garden rolls. the peanut dipping sauce was nothing special, a little on th sweet side for me, i think it needed a kick, some hot sauce of some sort. other than that, service was good. and i like their cups, with town/city names or thailand in traditional thai design with bright colors. i also tried my friends' pad thai, pineapple fried rice, and panang curry, and gai ga prow, all delish!

after this, we walked around and tried to digest our lovely meal. i just love strolling around castro area.
author: Pamela s.

description: Sexy people, sexy waiters, sexy me!  What else could you ask me?!  Please don't answer that ;).  The food here is amazing!  The flat noodle dishes are tres yummzies.  The location is perfect, the decor is sleek yet functional, and the people are super sexy.  Ok, I should be talking about the food, but doesn't food taste better with eye candy?  Go now! (or later).
author: Walter C.

description: I really wish they delivered but after a gazillion years in the hood I just frickin realized that the Thai House Express on Larkin & Geary is the same as the one on 18th & Castro...and I'm not blonde.  Sooooo much closer to home and work means I will be going there a lot more often which is bad for my wallet and waistline but oh so exciting.  We get the same thing every time - spring rolls, pad thai, and chicken red curry - and it's consistently good each and every time.   And the service is good to boot!
author: Julie P.

description: I've asked a classmate of mine that is Thai and happens to work at a Thai restaurant, where does she go when she is looking for an authentic reminder ot Thailand.  Her reply was Thai House Express in the Castro.  Man, was she right.  This place takes flavor to the extreme.  Having a dish mild and having it spicy the next time is almost like having two totally different dishes.  Be careful of asking for spicy because they mean it and it will hurt!  Everything I've had here is good and the staff is attentive.  Heads up, parking sucks.
author: Jason A.

description: Well I've lived in SF 6 years and tried many of Thai places.  Although many good ones, I think this is the best in the city. Consistent and decent price.  Vegetarian options too.  Be prepared to wait. Then again I might be bias cause it is one of the closest places to my house.
author: Scott L.

description: I've long been a fan of the Thai House restaurant on Market at Sanchez, and my first visit to this relatively new outpost pleased me greatly. The food and service are just as good as they are at the other location, and the ambience is even better. I look forward to trying all of my favorite dishes on subsequent visits, but for now, I can say with authority that the fried pouch appetizers, salmon with red curry sauce, pad see ew with chicken, and tofu with green beans were mighty tasty. Yay!
author: Tara M.

description: My favorite Thai spot in the city. Good prices, excellent veggie selection (love the soup!), and cool ambiance. I'm due for a visit soon.
author: Michie L.

description: I think this place used to be a dingy Chinese place with shady cabanas?  Redone not too long ago and i LOVE it!  I get the hugest cravings for the Thai beef jerky.  Great refreshing noodle soups (although sukiyaki was not really my fav, just a preference thing).  Basically I've tried many of the dishes, I'm never disappointed and always leave happy and full.  Fantastic addition to the 'stro.
author: Jason M.

description: One of only 2 places we order take out Thai food from - this has to be the best pad thai in the city.  Great location, food and atmosphere.  Clean and nice waiters/waitresses
author: Pug P.

description: Food was good, but the service blows.  Only people in the place w/2 servers but couldnt get a refill.
author: Brian B.

description:
It always strikes me funny, well not really, how many people have to sadly work in jobs that they seem to hate or at least not care for. 

One would think that in an industry (service) where a good number of its workers makes a living out of the tips they receive, they would give a shit.

Their service is terrible. The queens working there need to get a grip on that fact. 

Also, their menu has items priced at a lower price than what they charge you. I was there a couple months ago and they told me that they have just changed the prices and had not made the changes yet. I was there last week and that was the same lie they told me. WTF?!

Hopefuly they wont be around much longer.

I wish I could give them a lower rating.
author: alex s.

description: I used to eat here every once in a while a couple of years ago, and I really liked it.  But I came here last night and it was decidedly mediocre. The service was inattentive. The food was just ok. They didn't even ask us if we wanted dessert before they brought us the bill! There are many better Thai places out there.
author: Jen R.

description: I ordered a salad and asked for dressing on the side. They were not able to understand why, and didn't comply. Need more be said?
author: D E.

description: I've been coming here often for the past few years.  My experiences here are varied.  For the most part, the food and vibe are great.  It's a cute and fairly modern Thai restaurant in the heart of Castro.  It is often crowded and has a lively atmosphere.  That can also be a negative as sometimes the service SUCKS!  But even with that, I still keep coming back because it's fun and the food is always really good.  I recently had a green curry there and it was addictive.  Definitely one of the better Thai places in Castro.
author: Philip D.

description:
I tend to avoid meals in the Castro with a  few exceptions, but I was compelled to try Thai House Express for the rumored greatness of the kao ka moo, special pork leg stew. As a girl that grew up enjoying Peking Duck, suckling pigs, things wrapped in bacon, and well marbled steaks, I knew I would love this dish the moment I laid eyes on the rich fatty bits, pork skin, and soft braised meat of the kao ka moo! I wouldn't recommend powering through this on your own though, definitely a dish to share. Loved the spicy tangy sauce that came on the side and the crisp emerald green gai lain (Chinese Broccoli) hiding underneath the tender pork soaking up the yumminess.
Pad kee mao was also very good. Crisp veggies, fresh basil, pan fried rice noodles, and a spice level (we requested it spicy, even though it already had the chili notation on the menu) that was kickin'! Yeah, this was right at the threshold of excellent spicy flavor and an intense, fiery burning. I think it may be more pleasant to stick to the regular spicy level at T.H.E. b/c they are not messing around with the heat. If you like it spicy, get over there soon.
Nice modern space, friendly servers, water refilled regularly, and, even if the food wasn't as savory as it was, I would still love them b/c they're open late, til midnight or 1am on the weekend and 10 or 1030 during the week. About $18 for 2 dishes before tip.

*****************************************************************
Update 2/28/06-Went back and ordered the same 2 dishes again. Found the pork to be less succulent and fatty. Still good though, just not ambrosial. I was there at the busier dinner hour, so maybe sneaking in earlier or later is the key to allowing the kitchen to take their time?
author: Candice L.

description: So happy they have moved 2 blocks from my house! Very cool, clean space and of course, delicious Thai food. I do love their Pad Thai and Thom Yum Goon soup! There are always some good dinner specials and the curries are yummy!
author: Mariangela S.

description: My favorite Thai restaurant in SF. Not that I'm en expert on Thai food, but I really enjoy  it everytime I swing by. My fav, #21, beef salad, the sauce is just spectacular. It's also a great place to go with friends if it's a big group. I've showed up with parties of 12 and always been able to make a reservation just a few hours ahead and there's never been a problem.
author: Pablo C.

description: fast, cheap, and convenient location. nothing to rave about, but still consistent quality pad thai, pad seew, and garlic beef
author: Ben T.

description: Just when I think I know all the great Thai restaurants in the City.  I was proved wrong.  The papaya salad is very delish and they made it spicy when I asked for it.    I had the crispy tofu and green beans with chilli sauce and my friend had the green curry veggies.  Both were really good.  I would def come back.
author: Julia H.

description:
i love the variety in the menu!  service is promt and friendly!

**best thai tea
author: Kristen T.

description:
Not sure why this place so popular as the food just ok.
Service was  better than the food.
Been here twice   food just okay each time
author: kavin m.

description: We live nearby and this is our favorite Thai restaurant in the City.  The menu is not as extensive as other Thai places, but the food is excellent, especially the soups and curries.  We usually get take-out and it really is ready in 10 minutes.
author: Christine H.

description: I'm so pleased to report there is now somewhere worth eating in the Castro. Thai House Express in inexplicably better than its sister property at Market and Sanchez, and it's closer to my house, too. Fierce! Thai House Express is pretty charmless, but the service is generally good and the food better. As a general rule, I try to stray from the standards, and that's been a marvelously successful game plan as I've eaten my way from one end of the menu to the other. Particular favorites include the large Tom Yum soup (with sliced pork, ground pork, pork balls, and pork cracklings on top!), the homemade "beef jerky," the kao soi yellow curry noodles, pork leg stew, ba mee pork noodles, and sukiyaki noodles. Great flavors, generous portions. For what more could you ask of your neighborhood Thai place? How about flamingly homosexual Thai waiters? Check.
author: Jon L.

description: I've eaten here before. It didn't really wow me....maybe because I expect spicy food to actually be spicy. The food was good though....too bad my meal took a little longer than expected to arrive (20 minutes?!?!) so I looked pretty lame as the rest of my party got to eat and I got to play spectator. Still though, I'm a believer in second chances so I would visit this location again...if only for their curry dishes, delightful. :-)
author: James J.

description: This spot is a block from my new place, so I rolled down the hill and got some dinner w/ a buddy.  They do spicy right.  They do fish right.  They pretty much did everything right. I enjoyed the beef jerky appetizer (house specialty) and there was a lot of it.  You have to be in the mood for jerky though because it's a frustrating eat otherwise.  The portions are big, and  this is a fact because two big eating guys could not finish two entrees and an appetizer.  No problem though, take the rest home.  I'd definitely come here again.
author: Avi H.

description: I just want to say how impressed I am with not only the amazing tastes of the cuisine and how everytime I go to Thai House my food is spot on, but the speed is almost hard to believe! I mean its called Express but WOW...Impressive! I'd like to also say that staff that works at the restaurant are all very, very nice and it's a pleasure to walk in and be greeted by that GORGEOUS Thai staff! The yound woman who works there named Lek I believe..she's is the sweetest and definetly most humorous!
author: Jonah W.

description: Best thai in the Castro. Sure the service isn't the greatest but it's never affected my experience. I'll take quick, affordable and yummy pad kee mao over "good service" any day. There's no reason not to go. I also order out here on a regular basis.
author: Blake R.

description: My favorite Thai place in San Fran. Mint lemonade is pretty good too!
author: Austin R.

description: Very good food at reasonable prices! I love the atmosphere, and the fact that the staff works so well with one another. I thoroughly enjoyed the soup, we had the one with mushrooms, lemograss, chicken and bean sprouts, its a MUST! I hadnt found a thai place in SF that I was willing to call my own little spot but I have now offically found one!
author: Amanda P.

description: I really like this place. It's cheap, the food is good, and they fill your water all the time. It's hard to ask for more...maybe draft beer..?
author: Derek B.

description: This is my thai takeout of choice: fast, consistent, fresh, and yummy. This is not a mystery meat kind of place... even things that you might look skeptically at such as the "naked ladies" = raw shrimp salad, are quite good and not sketchy at all. The pineapple fried rice is addictive, and you should definitely check out the specials. Nice atmosphere for eating in, though gets crowded on weekend nights (and sometimes during the week, especially if there are events in the castro).
author: Carrie G.

description: You're like totally fine and ok and I eat you when I'm too lazy to walk somewhere else and I do like your little indoor trickly fountain.
author: Claire C.

description: There is nothing "express" about this place.  The food was pretty good, but I'm finding it pretty hard to forgive the service and wait.  We spent more than three hours here and most of it was waiting for our food.  We would have left it we thought we'd be able to get into another restaurant without waiting to get a table.  There were four of us and they sent out my food about one hour before my friends got theirs so I had to either eat in front my my starving friends or wait an hour and eat cold fish.  I think they may have totally forgot that we were there.  I might visit again someday but only at a time when business is very slow.
author: Campbell B.

description: Always have good quality food here.  The beef jerky sounds weird but is really delicious....and it doesn't hurt that I've been here 3 times and never paid!!  And no, I did not "dine and dash!"
author: Johnnie T.

description: Thank you, Yelp! This place is AMAZING!!!!!!!! I got the fried tofu over white rice. Wow. Plus the price is like $8! Small place though, you'll have to wait.
author: Tim M.

description:
I went there many times and it was great. I don't know what kind of expectations you have from neighborhood thai restaurant, but all I expect is a good food. I don't care about service. As long as my food and drinks are delivered, I'm happy. But man, their pad thai is so tasty. I also like eggplant dish, which is my favorite. 
I'm giving 5 stars as food is always good, service is sufficient, and it's just a few blocks from my house.
author: Tatsiana M.

description: Awesome food! Love the curries: yellow is really mild, the red is just hot enough. Hot & sour soup is excellent and filled with bamboo shoots and chicken. The peanut chicken is delicious as well, looks appetizing unlike other places where it ends up looking like infant vomit on top of veggies.
author: Alden C.

description: I have always been curious about this place and I wanted to try something new considering I have tried a lot of the restaurants on Castro. After a long day, I walk in and it's not busy. I am seated right away and look at their menu. I order the crispy catfish with green beans and brown rice. It smelled and tasted delicious. Minus on star because I asked for it to be extra spicy and found that it wasn't so had to add more hot sauce! But it is reasonably price and the staff friendly. I will definitely come back and I like the space inside...large and accomodating!
author: Mel P.

description:
We were here to see a movie at the Castro theater, and this place was right nearby.

I found the main meal (pad thai) to be pretty decent (it's a fairly safe standby when you can't eat mushrooms and don't like tofu).  Their beef salad was just WHOA way too heavy on the seasoning.

Prices were reasonable enough, and service was quick and attentive. 

Oh and from what I can tell, the terndy Braille Wallpaper they have on the walls doesn't say anything useful.  (Just repeated Q, Z, and punctuation)
author: Dan M.

description:
Yuck.

Just gave this place another chance and sadly things did not go well.  This *used* to be the best place for Thai in the neighborhood but lately things are on a definite downturn. 

For example, the thick raw red onions in Tom Kha Gai soup were sharp and overpowering and should have either been more thinly sliced or left in the broth longer to cook and mellow.  It was an amateurish culinary error.

The cucumber salad, a staple of Thai cuisine had dressing that was overly sweet.  Somehow the kitchen got the balance between the sweet and the acid all wrong.  Again, this is a basic thing that any Thai kitchen worth its salt should nail.

My main course was Pad Ma Keur (sauteed eggplant and chicken).  It was significantly overcooked, resulting in tough chicken and mushy eggplant.  One of my favorite Thai dishes, I was only able to get half of it down.

Lunch came with an appetizer called "Toons Gern Yueng"  - diced chicken fried in a pocket of springroll dough.  It was bland and dry...lacking much flavor and sporting a "fried wet sawdust" texture.  I deemed this inedible and only downed one bite.

The underlying theme here is lack of consistency.  Over the years I've had great meals here and awful meals here.  More recently it's been quite bad.  Today, I suspect, was my last visit.
author: Adam H.

description:
"there are no good places to eat in the castro."

everyone says this. hell, i've said it a few times myself. and, when looking at some of the options in other hoods like the mission or hayes valley, i'm inclined to agree.

but this doesn't mean that all restaurants in the castro are horrible. take thai house express, for instance. the food here is pretty good. maybe even great. i live close by and i continue to choose this place over other thai restaurants in the area. i can't write a better review than that.

their salted pork ribs are awesome.
author: Maveric V.

description: Hmmmm well went back after a loooong time and was just picking up to go - which was delicious btw (hence the two stars) - but have to say some (not all) of the guys working were anything but welcoming. Will probably consider going elsewhere next time even if I do live 5 doors away.
author: Tim Z.

description: I don't often write one star reviews, but this calls for one. I ordered the salted fish dish. The main dish on this plate was FISH. When my dish came out, the plate was full of green beans (which I love so that was great), but I couldn't find the fish? I dug around and finally came across 3 tiny cubes of meat. I am not exaggerating when I say tiny cubes. They were probably the size of my fingernail. I thought there might have been a mistake, maybe I got someone else's plate? I asked them about this possible mix-up and they explained that they only put in a tiny amount of fish in the dish because it is so salty. WHAT?! I tasted the dish - yup, it was so salty that it was disgusting. The green beans were also too salty. I drank 3 glasses of water for only a few bites. I left the rest of the dish untouched. What I'd like to know is, how does a restaurant create a dish that tastes so awful that they can only include a few pieces because no one can stand to eat more of it? I'm baffled.
author: E. N.

description: We shared some great dishes here, the peanut sauce on the tofu was great. The Pad Thai good, and corn cakes yummy. I would go here in a pinch if looking for Thai in the Castro. And there seemed to be good vegan and vegetarian options.
author: Alyssa C.

description: I have traveled and lived in Thailand for longer times and do think the food is great and very tasty. This is a place I recommend to my friends in town and out of town. As the response to the service I have always enjoyed the staff and service and think they are very polite, quick and friendly and they are one of the big reasons I always return. If you haven't been there for dinner or quick snack I do recommend you to give it a serious try.
author: Niklas L.

description: Absolutely the best Thai Food in the city. Apparently a clone of the acclaimed Thai House Express on Larkin, which I've never been to, item for item this recent Castro installment soars high above its paltry competitors. The Yen Tah Fo soup (seafood and noodles), the standard dish by which I judge all Thai restaurants, is incredibly tasty -- the perfect mix of spicy, tangy and sweet. Very generous with the seafood, too. There's plenty of vegetarian food also and oh! an otherworldly smooth coconut juice. All this and the prices are incredibly low, the staff is embarrassingly friendly and on Fridays and Saturdays they're open till midnight!
author: Davi M.

description: I'm going to start off by saying that I love Thai food.  I'm a huge fan and have been to over 30 Thai restaurants in the Bay Area.  I even visited Thai House Express when it first opened a couple of years ago.  I just had dinner there tonight and was very disappointed.  I had the fried snapper in  spicy sauce and the string beans with pork, both very standard dishes in terms of Thai food.  Both were extremely sweet and almost reminded me of Chinese sweet and sour pork.  I'm a big eater and this was a rare time that I took both dishes home after eating minimal amounts of each.  Funny thing is, the last time I dined there (2 years ago), the food was good.  Maybe I caught it on a bad day?
author: Terry F.

description: Wow do I love this restaurant.  I used to live in Thailand and I appreciate that when I tell the chef to prepare my food as if I were Thai, they actually do.  This is the friendliest restaurant in all of San Francisco, as far as I have experienced and the food is always fresh and flavorful, as Thai should be.  The crowd is hip and groovy and I always leave Thai House Express with a huge smile on my face - especially when I get the bill.  Wow.  Amazing food at these prices and a friendly Swasdee Krap.  Life in San Francisco is sweet thanks to Thai House Express!
author: Dann H.

description: Ok, now I really enjoy the food here.  I enjoy the red chicken curry and spicy jerky apetizer.  Always crowded but get seated promptly and good place to people watch if you get to sit by the window.
author: Denny R.

description: The food is the most inauthentic Thai food I have ever had. The pad thai which they claim is best in the city is nothing but noodles served with a sauce which tastes strangely like ketchup. It was too sweet and If I didnt have hot sauce to spice it up, it was totally without taste. the chicken satay was also tasteless as was the peanut sauce. They are surviving because of the location in the Castro. but the awful food will not carry it for long.
author: carmine g.

description: By far one of my favorite thai restaurant in SF... i think it's the ambiance that gets me goin' back to this place and also the wonderful larb salad hehehe yummy definitely but yeah imust say good service and yummy food... and there has been an occasion when they ran out of a dish and luckily they've apologized for it... either way.. still yummy =-)
author: Ryan M.

description: I really want to like this place because I am in the neighborhood every weekend and you can usually get a table without a wait. The food lacks something that I cannot put my finger on. The papaya salad was ordered medium spicy and it was so hot we could not eat it. The chicken curry was very good but served luke warm.  Several times the garnishes have been old and wilted....oh well, at least it is reasonably priced and easy to get into. I just think with the amout of Thai restaurants in the Castro ONE of them would be top notch.
author: James S.

description: Great noodle dishes and rice plates, and they did a great job of making the dishes very spicy.  The service was pretty good, and, as the name implies, the food came out quite quickly.  Highly recommended for good, quick Thai food.
author: Pilan C.

description: Overall good, cheap, nice clean atmosphere with very friendly staff and quick service. Limited vegetarian menu. Also -- Inconsistant with how spicy things are, sometimes 'really spicy' taste seasoned with butter and 'mild' makes you cry from the spicy goodness.  I also dearly miss Khun Phoa which contributes to the 3 star rating. Khun Phoa had a far superior vegetarian menu.
author: n s.

description: This is my neighborhood Thai joint.  Big bonus on being able to pick up tasty take-out while walking the dog.  Ah, I love multi-tasking.  Excellent pad thai and a nice setting too.  Modern and clean.  Like you would want to go there on a Friday night for dinner with some friends.  Pricier than most Thai places but the brown rice option is pretty cool.
author: Piper B.

description: Great place! I never found the restaurants in the Castro that great but this is an exception. I also like the presentation of the food on different plates, very pretty and I like pretty. I noticed the website, very snazzy but they can do without the trip hop Kruder/Dorfmeister like soundtrack it's distracting.
author: .James A.

description: Good food, so-so service. I had the Pad Thai, supposedly the best in the City. I thought it was really good, very moist and sticky in a good way-I'm not giving up on my hunt though. I went with a group of friends and everyone enjoyed their food, even my picky Laotian friend was satisfied and gave it the thumbs up. It is simple, modern decor-I wouldn't sat at tall counters again-it was hard to get on and off and the silver chairs were loud and scratchy. The prices are good for the quality. It took a while to order and to pay and they weren't even that busy. The servers weren't very polite or friendly as well.
author: Jenny W.

description: Food is inexpensive and quick. Staff is friendly.
author: Zach Z.

description: This restaurant is literally a block away from my home, and I had very high hopes for it.  Unfortunately, the food is standard, and the service leaves much more to be desired.  As others have posted, the restaurant is not uber family friendly.  We had an awful experience there with our then one-year-old child.  The staff was less than helpful with finding an appropriate place to seat us sans high chair, and provided barely any service as we watched them serve surrounding tables.  We have never dined in again, and that was 1.5 years ago.  If we are in pinch for dinner, we may order take out from Thai House Express, but otherwise we stay away.
author: Diana P.

description: I have to give this place a 5.  I'm addicted to their Salted Fish Rice, the Pad Thai, the Cashew Chicken, and their Chinese Sausage Rice.  I'm there every week and the staff recognize me.  The owner is very nice and polite and always happy to see me.  Now I have tried a few items here that I didn't like.  Including one crab salad that was ghastly.  99.9% of the time when I come here I have a great time.  The prices and portions are just right also.
author: Michael D.

description: I love this place!! So good and sooo cheap. Every time I come here the food seems very consistent and well prepared. I like the atmosphere and the service is usually great as well. Corkage fee for wine is not too bad either ($10 or $12) so you can get away with drinking cheaper wine and splitting the fee with friends. Im a fan.
author: Jared B.

description: Amazing, amazing, amazing.  One of the best, if not THE best, Thai restaurants in the city.  Whether you're strictly Pad Thai or experimental, you can't go wrong.  Their Pad See Ew is incredible, and their green curry might be the best I've had.  Try the Larb, too.  And don't forget to get Sticky Rice for dessert...oh, now I'm hungry,
author: Sheila W.

description: The decor leaves something to be desired, as it is just regular old tables and uncomfortable chairs.  I thought this place was supposed to be upscale?  Anyway, we ordered the vegetarian soup and the vegetarian pad thai without egg.  Neither was the best thai food that I have ever eaten, but I have no real complaints either.  Very solid.
author: Joanna S.

description: One of my favorite Thai places.  I like that it is often not that overcrowded, that staff is friendly and attentive.  The dishes rock fairly well, but there's something else.  The restaurant exists on the top floor of a former house on Castro with some of the fixings still in place like fireplaces.  It feels homey...and also being on a top floor enables a great view upon Castro should you snap a window table.  Eat languidly while viewing nameless hordes descending upon Castro and it's theatre a great place to momentarily escape the convivial chaos!
author: Femita J.

description: I don't know why this place bothers calling it Thai House Express. "Express" it is not. Didn't see a take-out counter or a waitress, for that matter. Having said that, it's the best Thai food in the Castro. It's really good. A huge menu w/ lots to choose from. I've yet to have a bad dish. Always delish with a tasty atmosphere.
author: Michael A.

description: Edible, uninspired pad thai. Kind of bland.  Ate there during lunch, at least is was quiet.  At night I have found the noise level supplemented by idiotic standard Castro music turned up too much.
author: Adam R.

description: I lived in Thailand for a year and this is the closest to authentic I've found in SF.  The one on Larkin is actually a little better but this location is more convenient to where I live.  The guys that work there are cool - friendly and efficient.  When I walk in they seat me at "my table" and bring me my usual drink before I'm even seated.  More often I take out - and they don't chintz on the portions when you do that (you know how annoying it is when you get less with take out vs. when you sit in the restaurant).  My favorites - Som Tom,  Gai Gra Pao, Neu Kem.  And they are consistent.  Which is key in my book.
author: Heather F.

description: We went there for a casual dinner on Friday.  What a surprise that this modern looking Thai Restaurant can make the most delicious duck salad--never had it so yummy before.  The must order is the vegetable curry and grilled beef with rice.  I took the leftover curry home and added some vegetable to it the next day for dinner. it's so good!!!  The portion is big and filling.  This place is going to be jammed with people but you will not disappointed!
author: John H.

description: My favorite Thai restaurant in the neighborhood, and perhaps anywhere.  Excellent ingredients, straightforward but solid menu, and nice presentation, served in a clean, minimalist decor.  Friendly staff seems to really enjoy working there.
author: nick w.

description: I've eaten here twice, and both times were pretty good.  Nothing exceptionally amazing about the food, but dishes were tasty and very reasonably priced, and service was quick.  Definitely the reliable choice when it comes to neighborhood Thai.
author: Marykay F.

description: For people like me who only get takeout when under the weather (otherwise enjoying the experience of being in a restaurant enough to always want to opt for that if I'm not cooking in), Thai House Express wins the blue ribbon for best comfort food in the city. A good Pad Thai is, in my mind, the only close rival of my mom's mac n cheese when I'm not feeling good. And Thai House Express has the best Pad Thai I've ever eaten. The rest of their offerings are also delicious, and when you're in the mood to dine in, the service is good and the wait is not usually too long, though the place is small and often packed.
author: Lara F.

description:
i have heard my favorites fernando and greg talk about this place and the servers who wear the designer jeans who work here etc. granted i do not know them i get the feeling fernando and greg are the only non cheesy morning radio show people who actually know a good thing or two - i was in the neighborhood and was hungry and saw this place and decided to have a try and ooooo it's good.
and for several reasons: cute interior, good music, and different things on the menu and it's affordable. 
four stars for one reason: they should have one of those curtains in front of the door when you walk in that blocks the draft when the door opens on cold nights.
author: melissa h.

description: My favorite Thai place (of all two i've been to). I ate something ... i got pad see eww; despite the name, it was gooooohooooood. cheap too.
author: Jaymes H.

description:
I am thorn between giving three or four stars... 

I really liked how the vegetables were cooked - the eggplant dish we tried was great!

However, the dishes were all very greasy. Hmm. 

The coconut juice was very refreshing, though. 

After all, I think I will still go back to try a few more dishes...
author: Sammy T.

description: Went here tonight and had a really great meal/experience. Quick seating at 8pm, fast, but not rushed felt relaxed. Friendly vibe with a lot of the staff and customers chatting a bit and hugging a few people. Ate the (vege)Padi Thai Pok, and it was great. The Entree was the vege spring rolls which were amazing. Will be heading back.
author: Wade M.

description: This place is dangerous.  Fast, delicious, reasonable prices, and 10 seconds from my apartment, it's hard to go anywhere else.  The pad thai is delicious if a little dry, but the green curry is fantastic, as are the spring rolls.  Excellent, easy, and nice.  Great combination of things.
author: Nate R.

description:
this is one of the best thai restaurants I've been to in SF.  
Try their Curry Noodle. It's to die for if you like curry.  
The service is good and fast, the restaurant is clean, the atmosphere is hip, and most importantly, the food is affordable.
author: amy l.

description:
according to my three criteria thai food analysis, this place only get's 3 stars becase:
1. their pineapple fried rice is mediocre and doesn't automatically come with shrimp as well as the meat of your choice.  the shrimp should be a staple.  plus, they don't use golden raisins in the recipe.  brown raisins are mediocre by comparison.
2. palm juice is on the menu, but very rarely in supply.  my advice is that they should remove it from the menu so that i don't go in there and get my hopes up only to have them dashed to smithereens.
3. the mango sticky rice is on point, but not enough to make up for the misses on points 1 and 2.

i do give them cool points for being conveniently located in the castro.  honorable mention also for the television that plays tbs and spike tv movies and for the friendliness of the staff.

overall great for pre and post drinking munchies when hanging out in the neighborhood.  get one of the tables by the window and watch the girlies (or boys) strolling down castro.
author: Lex E.

description: I generally get take-out and this place is consistently good and their prices are fair.  #64 with chicken or beef will give you plenty of pleasure with some left over for lunch the next day.
author: John A.

description: Great place for dinner or lunch. The menu is great and if you like Thai food this is the place to go. Get there early for dinner because they always have a line in the evenings. Service is great., Love it!!!
author: Miguel E.

description: the food was really good. my gf , her friend and I had dinner here the other night. We enjoyed 2 order of tom yum noodle soup, something that not to many places do, 3 spice fish which was really good and the portion was large. our last dish was some kai yang (grilled chicken) with sweet sauce. The prices are alittle be more and the parking can suck at times but I really liked this place. We'll be back soon.
author: william w.

description: A nice looking place from the outside and nice decor inside.  That being said I found the Pad Thai there to be very bland and tasteless.  I ordered mine spicy and was met with a spiceless dish.  Much better options in the neighborhood.
author: Todd L.

description:
Be careful - the waiters, which are all asians, were very rude to me and my boyfriend. We went in there, asked to be seated and the waiter did not say a word, just took the menus and sat us down. When we asked him why the bad attitude, he responded by saying "do you want to stay or not"? We were shocked with the bad attitude. We heard from our friends that the waiters made the dining experience terrible but didn't believe it. After going there, I can safely say "BEWARE OF THAI HOUSE CASTRO - AWFUL SERVICE AND ABUNDANT WITH BAD ATTITUDE".

I will never go there again and will let all of my friends know that they should stay away too.
author: js w.

description: This was not a good experience.  Service was terrible, food not very good.  I had one of the specialties, which was described as "chicken" on the menu, arrived ground beyond recognition, greasy as hell.  The overall taste was impossible to pinpoint, which I found disturbing, as well as a spine-chilling bit of texture when I found my teeth crunching on bone fragments.  I'm not going back.
author: Billy Dee R.

description: They do have one waiter with an attitude or maybe he's always having a rough day, but hey the food is YUMMY.  I'd go here any evening. Not Osha prices either, which is great for my digestion as well.
author: Shwin S.

description: This was my first Thai food experience, and it was a good one.  Lots of things were tasty... chicken with vegetables in green curry sauce, deep-fried tofu, seafood salad, and my new-found favourite, traditional peanutty-flavoured pad thai.  The sweet-and-sour cucumber salad and sticky rice sides were also a nice complement.  As for the atmosphere, the place was decorated in a simple, modern style, and you can't beat a walk along Castro Street after your meal, the neighbourhood has such a personality!  Only word of advice: we ordered the foursome and sate appetizers, and were disappointed at the tiny amount of food they were for their $8 price tag.  Just order entrees straight away; for the same price range, you get a much larger amount of food.
author: Canadian A.

description: This is the best Thai food around, and I'm pretty picky.  Definitely order the Thai beef salad--it's better than any I've tried anywhere!  AND the prices are reasonable.  My roommates and I go there all the time as a default great and cheap place to eat great Thai food.
author: Jay K.

description:
i went a few years without eating thai...then i moved near the speediest little thai house this side of the pacific.  the green curry chicken and pad thai are the go to dishes...the cucumber salad is great, too.  make sure you go with the brown rice for that healthy finish.

btw, the thai iced tea is delicious!
author: Chris G.

description: Definintely one of the better thai restaurants in SF. Thai food is known for being spicy, and Thai house express makes its food SPICY...Whenever I go into a restaurant and ask for extra spicy, the waiters seem to ignore my request; however, Thai house express makes its food so spicy, that I have to dip my tongue in a glass of water to ease the pain. THe only thing I order here is Pad ga prow. It is the best I have ever eaten, and I've eaten at quite a few thai places. It is flavorful yet not over salty. My girlfriend ordered the pad se ew and she thought it was good. Overall, if you are a spicy eater, i recommend this place. You will not regret it.
author: huy P.

description: yum yum yum i don't really remember it too well because it was awhile ago, but the pad see ew was damn good.
author: Ronny K.

description: mmmm yummy vegetarian tom kah and great curries.  i don't understand the point of the decor but that is ok.  also the spring rolls are a little too thick for my taste, i'd prefer them to be thinner so they are easier to bite.  but yeah, all in all, great food and a good lunch spot (the lunch special is the way to go).  oh and there's one waiter there who is SO nice.
author: paige m.

description:
ok so im not gay but i had heard that this place had the good grub, and it's near my crib so i went to check it out. i love thai food, and i love the dried chili mix they have to sprinkle on your noodles. 
   i ordered a special, noodles with dungeness crab, and a soup, tom gai, and a beer. the window was open and the waiter seemed to be in a different world. he never brought the beer, but i let it go. water was ok, and i just wanted to eat. however, i just knew that would show up on the ticket at the end. whatever, i would deal with that later.
   the soup came quick and it was fantastic. i was thinking, damn this is the spot, they had on a radio station that was playing some good electronic music and the soup was out of this world. the waiter came by and refilled my water, i laughed inside that he had totally forgotten, but it was alright as long as he didn't charge me. i was still planning a big tip for the service. 
   the noodles came and i was elated. i put the chili powder on them and dug in. some of the best thai noodles i had ever tasted, they were perfectly cooked. the sauce was exquisite and i was very satisfied with the service up to this point. i left the table to go to the bathroom. like a good boy, i wash my hands. the sink had a very "ultra modern" faucet, and it took me a hot second to figure out how to turn the sucker on. i turn it to the middle and run my hand under it quickly. DAMN IT WAS HOT. steam started coming up at me out of nowhere and my hand was scalded from just a seconds exposure. that shit pissed me off. plus i got water all over the front of my khaki pants. i go back to the table and ask for the check the first chance i get. some other waitress brings it to me and, of course, the beer i ordered is on there. i feel some sympathy for the waiter because i can see that he is very busy with to-go orders on the phone and plenty of other tables. it's just inexcusable when they just don't pay attention. don't charge people for drinks you don't bring. it took me a little while to get it worked out, because i needed change and had to wait for a new check. i left with the best taste in my mouth, and the worst, not to mention my hand had red marks on it for a day.
author: oskar p.

description: Tonight was my second visit to Thai House Express on Castro.  At my first visit several weeks ago I had AMAZING food and a nice server.  I was excited to go back.  Unfortunately, because of the rudeness of the person who sat us tonight - a tall gentleman wearing a vest and a hat - I left without ordering.  When we came in the gentleman in the vest greeted us and offered us one of two tables by the front door.  I asked for another table - without requesting a specific one - explaining that it's cold tonight and I didn't have a jacket (also, my boyfriend gets cold easily).  My boyfriend asked about a booth in the middle of the restaurant, and was told that it was only for parties of four.  There were many empty tables (it was after 8:00 p.m.), but fair enough.  I understand they need to maximize seating options.  We then suggested one of the tables in the back, up a few steps; he took us back there while rolling his eyes and acting annoyed.  When I thanked him for seating us, he barely acknowledged me.  I felt slighted and very unwelcome in the restaurant.  But still, I wanted to stay for the yummy food and cute decor.  I can't even remember the last time I left a restaurant.  As my boyfriend and I were discussing what to do, we noticed the gentlemen in the vest lingering behind us, ostensibly pouring water, but actually giving us dirty looks.  His behavior was completely unacceptable.  Our request to be seated away from the door was made politely and was not unreasonable.  There were plenty of free tables and we were the only ones waiting to be seated.  We left before we ordered and I won't be back.  Instead, we had a lovely meal at Brandy Ho's.  Our server was very nice and we left her a 33% tip.  If I were the owner/manager of Thai House Express on Castro, I would be very concerned about the gentleman in the vest's poor attitude.  Customer service is what keeps diners coming back, and everyone thinks carefully about where (s)he spends money during a recession.
author: Steven W.

description: I've eaten here more times than I can count. It's a good thing it is only 1.5 blocks away. The food here is really some great Thai. It's a rare event when I get something that's off, maybe salty, or maybe I shouldn't have tried to be so adventurous. Overall, the food is consistently great. The rice plates are enough for a satisfying meal, and are a great option at a great price for many of their dishes. If I'm feeling ravenous the entree + rice is satiating. The Money Bags appetizer is my favorite. All their curries are good....with exception to the Panang Curry w/ Beef. It breaks my heart that this dish isn't (in my opinion) good. I LOVE Panang Curry. The Thai House Beef dish is mouth watering, and that spicy green dipping sauce with citrus and garlic will stick with you as a constant reminder of how good it was. It's the best place for takeout, I just wish they would hop on board with online & app based ordering. I can order my food, walk out the door and by the time I'm there it's waiting for me.
author: Mike P.

description: The hostess threw menus at us while we were still waiting for a table and came back frantic-eyed, asking if we were ready, saying we had to order NOW, the cook was threatening to close down the kitchen!  He won't take any more orders after this minute!  So we saved them the trouble and left.
author: Julia T.

description: it's open late. the gaysian staff are sassy with their premium denim diesels filling out the ABS (asian butt syndrome) and their baby tees. the food is prolly the best in the stro which is known for restaurants that are comparable to cafeteria, airline and frozen dinners. they don't dumb down the flavors. the best part of coming here is when i scream "Ti ga Ti ga, dersa tiger!" then you see all the thai people working there run out the door like the degenerates at the SF zoo christmas 07.
author: dan T.

description: I've come here numerous times ordering my favorite dish, and 9 out of 10 times they get my order wrong. I keep coming back hoping it would be different, but it never was. What's really upsetting is the staff, who pretend to nod their head and say yes yes yes, they end up never putting in my order correctly. Every time I bring my food home, it's wrong.  I just don't understand what's so hard about granting a customer their request on how they like the dish to be made, and honestly, It's the easiest request..."cook the meat well done for me please." IT'S RAWISH EVERY TIME! On top of that, the little guy who sits at the desk wearing make up gives you attitude left and right. I am very polite, smile, be extra sweet, yet they still won't put in my order correctly. I've stopped coming here all together. Now, I get that same dish at Thai Chef down the street by Badlands, and what do you know, they get my order right every time.
author: Kevin T.

description: Fast and friendly service, but I wasn't impressed with the food. The beef seemed overcooked and dry, and the Panang curry was very oily. I've been here in the past and remembered it being better... but oh well, I was there late at night on a Sunday.
author: Ashley P.

description: i like their food but bad costumer service,my friends and i ate lunch there one time  on Sunday . the host  was horribly got an attitude towards his fellow Asians but when it comes to white folks he was so nice.my friends and i agreed that we never gonna go back there anymore for bad experience, anyway there's some more Thai resto around the city.but definitely not those Thai resto down Castro coz seems like the same owner,piece of advice to the management!!improve costumer service with Asians  alone coz seems like their just nice with white folks and other race
author: jack s.

description: I went to this place a while back on a weeknight. It was a return trip. I've always thought the food was pretty good and, even though the crowd was thick and the men were A&F plastic, I wanted to go back to support the local business.  And then I went on a week night and was cheated on my bill.  The waiter was young and muscled and acted very dumb. When the bill arrived, it seemed excessively high, but we only had a stub to go on....  After insisting, he brought our bill all written in Thai after about 5 minute.  But he had used white out to try to cover a charge that was sitting on our bill.  We asked him what it was and he kept saying it was for drinks (that we didn't have).  I guess his business was slow that night so he thought it was OK to charge extra and we wouldn't notice.   I would give Thai House Express the lowest rating (no stars if possible).  If you DO go there, watch your bill like a hawk.  White out.  Give me an F'ing break.
author: joe c.

description: this is my take out place du jour. pretty tasty. if only they delivered, they would get more stars from lazy me.
author: julia r.

description: Some of the best Thai food in the city. Love the corn cakes and pad thai.
author: Anna J.

description: i like this place and so does my Thai friend.....uhm that says something about a Thai restaurant.  Their cuisine seems like it's down home Thai food and the thai sausage appetizer dishes says it all, it's sooo good and it's what you find in like a down home cooking thai place.  We had a couple of beef dishes (i forgot the name cause i was there a month ago) but it was very good, not overly sweet and very nicely seasoned.  The service was very good also but then again having someone who speak thai with you does help hahhaha
author: joshua g.

description: my favorite thai food restaurant in the castro, i especially love the thai beef salad, they now how spicy i always want it when i come in here!
author: Victor M.

description: whatever that salmon dish was? chu-chee, or chee-chu? it was absolutely fantastic! service good, tables a little bit close to each other...it is hard to get in and get out of the table.
author: Davey J.

description: This is my favorite Thai place in Castro.  We call it "Thai on the Corner" because we can't remember the name.  Prices are reasonable and some of the dishes delicious.  I especially like Pork Leg Stew over rice.  (It tastes better than it sounds).  I keep returning for the Panang Curry as well.  Some of the waiters are cute and sweet.  It doesn't have the cozy ambiance of some places but it is fast and reasonably efficient with fair prices. It is definitely on my list of regular places to eat.
author: Dan B.

description: i've been to this place like 4 times because it's conveniently located in the castro and also because I keep forgetting how consistently terrible the service is. There are a few servers there that always seem to have a sourpuss face, just plain unapologetically disengaged and unhappy about working there. The food is ok but definitely not good enough to deal with the attitude.
author: keith t.

description: been there 3 times. food is pretty good. nice sized menu. still doesent stack up to OSHA though...
author: Ryan B.

description: good food for the prices , but the want u to eat and get the fuck outta there especially when they are busy they get u the check without asking and pick up ur plate before u finish eating i would eat there again but i think i will order and pick up its a prett clean place ,
author: NAEL K.

description: i heart asian food place lunch specials.  this place has good choices with fun little sides.  i spent a whole $15 because i got a coke and tipped large.  will try to make this a regular hood stop when i can.
author: e w.

description: I was kept waiting 15 minutes at the door when i could see plenty of  open seating in the back. When I was finally seated I told my waiter that I was really hungry. It was another 10-15 minutes before I could flag him down to take my order. I asked for Pad Thai and requested that they put no MSG in it. I know that Pad Thai already has a bit because of the fish sauce, but my dish must have come loaded with it. Sure it tasted good, but I ended up with the worst migraine I have had in months. The food did arrive promptly after ordering. When I asked for the chili, sugar, lemon combo that often accompanies Pad Thai, I waited ten minutes and then had to walk up to the waiter and ask him to bring it. When I asked for chop sticks he slammed a container on the table. So they basically ignored my request for no MSG, gave me incredibly poor service, and a migraine that is a unhappy reminder of my time there. Needless to say, I won't be going back.
author: sf g.

description: I would have given 5 stars for the food, but the cute waitress boys care very little about being attentive and taking orders! We had to wait FOREVER for them to notice our waving to come by and take our order...the pad thai dish was very good with plenty of fresh shrimp and tofu. Their duck curry is also quite good. Overall, this is a "keeper" restaurant and we are going to come back! :D
author: E M.

description: The food quality is inconsistent. Stay away from the Param Pak, which is supposed to be tofu and MIXED vegetables, but they'll give you tofu and CABBAGE. I've ordered this 3 times and have never received mixed vegetables, just cabbage. 3 strikes and you're out. The wait staff is robotic.
author: x x.

description: I have to say, this place was pretty disappointing. I was really hungry and wanted some good Thai food. I came here with two friends and kept asking for a table. Some guy working there kept regarding us, would come halfway over to us, then forget he had something else to do. It took him three times to come back to us when he got us to sit at one table towards the front which was fine with us. We ordered and they said a booth was ready which was nice of them so we moved over there. One of my friends was in a hurry to get to work and they served him relatively quickly, the other two of us were fine to wait. What's really weird is everything tasted great for like the first two bites, then I was done with it. The duck curry I ordered was gross. The fat wasn't crisp like it should've been and was just chewy and honestly awful. The Pad Thai was too sweet, and the muck of oily shit my friend ordered wasn't good either. 'Sukiyaki' or something which is supposed to be Japanese. Wouldn't ever return. Narsty.
author: Geoffrey W.
